title: Brexit news update Pimlico Plumbers sign Charlie Mullins latest
story: Speaking on LBC, the Pimlico Plumbers boss told Andrew Castle he will not take down his offensive anti-Brexit sign until the Government calls for a second referendum on leaving the European Union.Mr Mullins argued he would be prepared to take the matter to court and even end up in prison over his anti-Brexit cause.The sign - which reads B******s to Brexit - was deemed as unrelated to Mr Mullins' company by Lambeth Council who requested the sign to be removed as soon as possible.But Mr Mullins refuses to take the sign down on the basis Brexit relates to his and every other business in the country that will be economically affected by the decision to leave the EU.                'May's plan is B******S!' Even this FERVENT Remainer condemns May plan                'Is it wise?' Pimlico Plumbers founder grilled over anti-Brexit signHe said: Quite clearly Brexit it very much about our business. It's not coming down.I'm a Remainer and looking for a People's Vote, and it's not coming down until we get that.If it means going to prison over it, then that's what I'll do.&ldquoWe need to make a stand for businesses and I don&rsquot believe that British businesses or just normal people should see their livelihoods go away just because Theresa May wants to leave the EU.Brexit news: Charlie Mullins claims he is prepared to go to prison over his anti-Brexit sign (Image: &bullPIMLICO PLUMBERS)The millionaire plumber pledged his support for a second&nbspBrexit&nbspreferendum predicting British voters will reverse the results of the 2016 referendum.Mr Mullins, who in March announced he would support the Lib Dem leader Vince Cable in his attempts to stop Brexit, has long claimed to leave the&nbspEuropean Union&nbspwould have negative effects on the country.Speaking to&nbspLBC over the summer, the Pimlico Plumbers tycoon said: We need a second referendum. We need to speak out.I'm telling you now, we won't be leaving the EU. I don't care what anybody says. We won't be leaving because the British people aren't that stupid any more.Mr Mullins insisted the people would be unhappy if the Government failed to set up a new referendum on the final terms of the Brexit withdrawal agreement struck with Brussels.He also reiterated the UK economy would suffer from leaving the bloc: People are going to be very unhappy if we don't have a second vote.We now know the facts. We're not prepared to put up with what we're being told, lies, ahead of us. What bit do the government not understand? Brexit is not good for the economy and for the people.But a Deltapoll survey of 1,094 adults published in August suggested that one in four Briton want the Government to deliver Brexit, with only 31 percent backing a new in-out referendum.Asked whether the UK should simply leave the EU on March 29, 2019 40 percent of respondents said they were in favour &ndash including 19 percent of former Remain voters.

title: Brexit news update Peoples Vote second referendum Sir Alan Duncan latest
story: Speaking on BBC Radio 5's Pienaar's Politics, the Tory MP dismissed claims the UK could re-join the European Union a few years Brexit was fully implemented by a deal with Brussels.Sir Alan argued, despite some people might be surprised by the final agreement Prime Minister Theresa May will reach at the end of the negotiations, the 2016 Referendum result will nonetheless be implemented with a new contract with the EU.&nbspHe said: &ldquoI think once we&rsquove left, we&rsquove left.&ldquoThere&rsquos no doubt that at the referendum people were voting for a concept rather than a contract.                Sting and Ed Sheeran JOIN Bob Geldof's latest anti-Brexit attack                Sturgeon reveals plan to SINK Brexit and break up UK&ldquoAnd now we&rsquore having to define that contract so inevitably maybe some people will say &lsquoOh I didn&rsquot see that coming&rsquo.&ldquoBut then that&rsquos what referenda do and we are bound by the referendum so we are going to have to negotiate the best deal for the country consistent with the outcome of the referendum.Asked whether there could be a possibility of a second Brexit vote - as called for by supporters of the People's Vote - Sir Alan quickly provided BBC host John Pienaar with a simple reason a second referendum with the option to remain in the EU could never be provided by the Government.He said: &ldquoI think that&rsquos fanciful. A three-way referendum?Brexit news: Sir Alan Duncan claims legislation for a second referendum would never pass by March 29 (Image: TRT&bull)&ldquoI mean, first of&nbspall,&nbspyou&rsquove got to get the legislation through and it ain&rsquot going to be though before the 29th March.&ldquoSo it ain&rsquot going to happen.It comes as Prime Minister Theresa May renewed her pledge to block calls for a second vote on Brexit at the Conservative Party Conference claiming a second referendum would be a politicians' vote.Mrs May said: &ldquoThere are plenty of prominent people in British politics &ndash in Parliament and out of it &ndash who want to stop Brexit in its tracks.&ldquoTheir latest plan is to hold a second referendum. They call it a People&rsquos Vote.&ldquoBut we had the people&rsquos vote. The people voted to leave.&ldquoA second referendum would be a politicians&rsquo vote: politicians telling people they got it wrong the first time and should try again.&ldquoThink for a moment what it would do to faith in our democracy if &ndash having asked the people of this country to take this decision &ndash politicians tried to overturn it.&ldquoThose of us who do respect the result &ndash whichever side of the question we stood on two years ago &ndash need to come together now.&ldquoIf we don&rsquot &ndash if we all go off in different directions in pursuit of our own visions of the perfect Brexit &ndash we risk ending up with no Brexit at all.

title: brexit news japan trans pacific partnership tpp uk membership shinzo abe eu
story: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said Britain would still be a nation &ldquoequipped with global strength after the split.And he said he would back any attempt by the UK to join the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP).The 11-nation bloc accounts for more than 13 percent of the world&rsquos wealth and includes Canada, Mexico, Vietnam and Australia.Brexiteers have touted the ability for the UK to strike global trade deals as one of the main benefits of leaving the EU.                Macron makes Brexit move: France set to snatch major Japan bank                'They are DESPERATE to save EU' Brexit has terrified 'Brussels bubble'International Trade Secretary Liam Fox announced the UK&rsquos interest in joining the TPP in July and said he would consult the public about a possible membership bid.The agreement had originally included the United States but President Donald Trump withdrew shortly after taking office.The remaining 11 countries involved decided to go ahead regardless, but Mr Trump has since singalled the US could join TPP after negotiating new terms.The combined GDP of the bloc currently totals some &pound10.3trillion, compared to the &pound14.5trillion of the EU.Brexit news: Shinzo Abe said the UK would be welcome in the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade bloc (Image:  IMAGES)Mr Abe said the UK would still have 'global strength' after Brexit (Image:  IMAGES)The TPP consists of 11 states including Japan, Mexico and Canada (Image:  IMAGES)                Has the EU BACKED DOWN? Ireland signals huge Brexit BREAKTHROUGH                Lloyd's boss reveals plans for Brussels transfer 'ACCELERATING' However if the US were to join, TPP would account for &pound21.3trillion or 36 percent of the world&rsquos wealth.In an interview with the Financial Times published today, Mr Abe said Japan would support a membership bid by Britain.He said while the UK would lose its role as a gateway to the EU after Brexit, it would still have a major role to play on the world stage.He also urged both sides in the deadlocked Brexit talks to use &ldquowisdom to reach a compromise and ensure there is a transition period to avoid a &ldquodisorderly Brexit.Mr Abe is one of Theresa May's closest international allies (Image:  IMAGES)Japanese firms have spent more than &pound40billion in Britain, encouraged by successive Governments since Margaret Thatcher promised them a business-friendly base from which to trade across the continent.Mr Abe&rsquos comments come after Japanese businesses this week warned of the potential impact of a no-deal Brexit.Car manufacturer Nissan, which employs around 8,000 people in the UK, said a hard Brexit which sees Britain fall back on World Trade Organisation rules would have &ldquoserious implications for its operations.A statement from the firm said: &ldquoFrictionless trade has enabled the growth that has seen our Sunderland plant become the biggest factory in the history of the UK car industry, exporting more than half of its production to the EU.&ldquoToday we are among those companies with major investments in the UK who are still waiting for clarity on what the future trading relationship between the UK and the EU will look like.Donald Trump withdrew from the TPP in 2017 but has suggested the US could join on new terms (Image:  IMAGES)Meanwhile, Toyota&rsquos Europe boss Johan van Zyl warned failure to clinch a Brexit deal could lead to a production stoppage at the company&rsquos UK plant at Burnaston in the East Midlands.Speaking at the Paris Motor Show this week, he said: The reason that many manufacturers are in the UK is because they were able to export duty-free to the European market.The UK market alone is not big enough to justify a plant of this size, so if we can no longer sell to the European market, it will have an impact on the future of the plant.

title: Brexit news theresa may conservative party brexiteer leave EU customs union
story: Brexit news: Theresa May has been sent an ultimatum from Brexiteers (Image: )The stark message from Brexiteer hard-liners has set a deadline of the next scheduled General Election until the UK must sever all ties with EU&rsquos Customs Union.A senior Brexit supporter told The Times: &ldquoAfter that we can&rsquot know who will be in charge, so we must be fully out by then.Mrs May intends this week to break the current impasse with the EU over the so-called Irish &ldquobackstop - which is a way to solve the border question.The Prime Minister plans to unlock the stalemate by offering a commitment to keep all of the UK in the bloc&rsquos current customs arrangements after the transition period ends in December 2020.                Brexit &rsquoINGENIOUS PLAN&rsquo: Whips trying to FORCE Labour to back ChequersJacob Rees-Mogg lambasted the concession as a &ldquoserious breach of Brexit - but senior Tories on Sunday hinted they were willing to allow Mrs May room for manoeuvre.But despite Mrs May&rsquos attempted goodwill gesture, EU bosses have been quick to dash hopes that extending EU customs arrangements by up to 18 months would be enough to break the deadlock.A European ambassador said: &ldquoAvoiding a hard border in Ireland has to be an all-weather fix &mdash that means British election-proof.The Prime Minister faces a difficult political choice over the ongoing discussions about a so-called temporary customs arrangement.Theresa May spoke at the Conservative Party conference in Birmingham last week (Image: )She must either strike a controversial deal with Brussels - and risk further Cabinet resignations - or walk away from the talks.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab is understood to be among Mrs May&rsquos Cabinet dissidents who oppose the idea of striking a deal with Brussels that ties the UK to EU customs arrangements indefinitely.The pressure is,&nbsptherefore, piling on the Prime Minister to walk a delicate line between keeping her domestic allies happy and coming to an acceptable compromise with the EU.Prominent Brexit supporter Sir Bernard Jenkin appealed to other Leave-backing MPs last week to warn that &ldquoan extended period in the customs union will make Brexit seem interminable and the Conservatives will be seen to have botched Brexit.                Sturgeon reveals plan to SINK Brexit and break up UK                May launches CHARM OFFENSIVE for Labour votersTheresa May is about to enter the most critical stage of talks with the EU (Image: )Sir Bernard said his colleagues would not vote down the autumn budget - but other Leave figures have conceded privately it was inevitable rebels would use the Chancellor's fiscal statement to ratchet up pressure on Mrs May.As talks with the EU enter a critical stage this week, Brussels is expected to reject key facets of Mrs May&rsquos Chequers deal.But the block is hinting at a compromise on the proviso the UK extends customs arrangements beyond December 2020.The 2022 deadline gives the Prime Minister a firm time period in which Brexit advocates in the Commons will remain on-side.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab doesn't want a deal that ties to UK to EU customs rules indefinitely (Image: )Japanese Prime Minister Sinzo Abe says he will welcome 'with open arms' a trans-Pacific trade deal (Image: )Mrs May&rsquos Brexit dilemma intensified on Sunday after Japan&rsquos prime minister Shinzo Abe insisted his country would welcome &ldquowith open arms the UK into a trans-Pacific trade deal.But the deal would require the UK to free itself from EU customs rules, which adds to Mrs May&rsquos political headache.Japan&rsquos leader also said Mrs May should minimise Brexit&rsquos impact on Japanese enterprise in the UK.Mr Abe told the Financial Times: &ldquoI truly hope that the negative impact of Brexit to the global economy, including Japanese businesses, will be minimised.

title: Brexit news lincolnshire port booming post brexit
story: Traffic is growing on the south bank of the Humber (Image: Glen Minikin)In the North Lincolnshire town of Immingham, no one is fretting over the snail-paced Brexit negotiations because, deal or no deal, they are already seeing the benefits of independence.In the past 40 years there has been a steady decline in the region with thousands of jobs lost as neighbouring Hull and Grimsby became casualties of the shattering demise of the shipbuilding and fishing industries.But Immingham has bucked the downward trend, with its docks steadily growing against the backdrop of decline in the area.And now the town is bursting with confidence that Brexit will usher in a new era of prosperity, as the Humber estuary prepares to take full advantage of an influx of new trade through its largest port.                Brexit 'INGENIOUS PLAN': Whips trying to FORCE Labour to back Chequers                'Abandon customs union by 2022 or risk BOTCHED Brexit&rsquo say Brexiteers There has been a surge in interest from companies looking for new routes into the UK amid concerns that Dover could become gridlocked.Associated British Ports (ABP) has announced a &pound36million investment in its container terminal at Immingham, having spent &pound14million in Hull last year.Higher capacity would bring a huge influx of jobs to Immingham, which is well placed as more than half the cargo entering Britain via the south coast is destined for the North.Relaxed As well as ABP's proposed expansion, shipping line DFDS has increased its Immingham operation by 10 per cent in anticipation of the Brexit effect.Immingham and neighbouring docks want to become free ports, avoiding tax and duties currently being levied by Brussels.A cross-party group of MPs has been formed to fight for free port status, demanding that imports and exports should take place without trade barriers.The port of Immingham is looking forward to a post-Brexit boom (Image: Glen Minikin)Chairman and Cleethorpes Conservative MP Martin Vickers said: I am very relaxed about whether we get a deal in the Brexit negotiations, because whatever the outcome I feel certain this area can thrive.Free ports are not just a vehicle to boost the national economy.They will be a great boost to coastal communities, some of which are badly in need of regeneration.The Humber in past years has been somewhat left behind. But now there is so much to be positive about and we must capitalise on the potential trade possibilities that Brexit is throwing up. We are seeing real opportunities and there is good cause for a new feeling of optimism.Anne Tate, northern Lincolnshire manager for the Hull and Humber Chamber of Commerce, said: A hard Brexit would certainly have the potential to help this area. We welcome any expansion of trade through Immingham and have the transport infrastructure to keep up with increased demand.Local worker Jo Macfarlane believes the local economy is booming (Image: Glen Minikin)Increased trade through the port would reverberate through other local contract industries and assist not only the logistics sector but also many other supply industries.Jo Macfarlane, 52, who works at the independent clothing store Lou Lou's Muse in the centre of town, said: Things are moving in the right direction, there's a buzz about the place. Two major new shops have opened and there's a better, more positive atmosphere in town.More traffic through the docks is good news for me and my husband because he's a truck driver.It's good for business here too because it'll mean more jobs and more people spending.On a run-down terrace on Queens Road, which twists towards the docks' southern entry point, new businesses are opening to take advantage of passing trade. Steven Scriver, 63, works for coach operator Sherwood Travel. He said: I voted to leave because millions were going to Brussels when areas like this were declining.Only two or three weeks ago the old loco depot was demolished. It was built when this area was thriving and transporting coal to power stations and oil from the refineries. It's great news to see some growth and investment in the docks again. This is what we hoped and expected when we voted to leave the EU in the first place and now we're about to see it happening.

title: Canada Loch Ness Monster Ogopogo sightings legendary creature
story: A mysterious sea creature has been spotted three times in the last month swimming in Lake Okanagan, Canada.According to stunned locals, the beast is suspected to be the legendary lake monster known as&nbspOgopogo, or Canada's Loch Ness monster.The Ogopogo is said to have a long body with several bumps and the head of a horse.Indigenous communities in Canada have long told stories and myths about the alleged existence of the animal.                Thames whale LIVE: Fears for Benny Beluga as it heads BACK to London                WATCH: Bikini girl spots this underneath herHowever, now locals have caught what they believe to be the&nbspOgopogo on camera multiple times.David Halbauer&nbspwas the first to spot the creature, which has set off the frenzy of mysterious activity.While he was out on a local beach, he saw a 15m-long&nbspdinosaur-like&nbspcreature emerge from the water.Mr Halbauer's cellphone footage of the mysterious object has gone viral and prompted renewed interest in the legend.A mysterious sea creature has been spotted three times in the last month (Image: )He said: When you're sitting by the beach on a sunny day you don't expect to see a dinosaur come out of the water.I saw this black form come out of the water &mdash cylindrical &mdash and then roll.&ldquoIt rolled up and down as it went in the water. Another lump of the same thing came up about five metres in front of it.Since Mr Halbauer's video,&nbsptwo more people have described recent encounters with the beast - with new footage emerging as well.One of the sightings was reported from the 22nd floor of a downtown highrise overlooking the lake.Another was spotted from a balcony in the 4000-block of Lakeshore Road in Kelowna, who recorded what appears to be the creature's head.Bill Steciuk, a local legend hunter who tracks sightings of the&nbspOgopogo, said the recent surge in activity had left him stunned.He claims that the recent influx of reported sightings are the first in a number years.Mr Steciuk has his own theory about the monster, claiming that the lake was once open to the ocean.He speculated that a sea creature swam up and became trapped once the waters receded to their current levels.

title: meghan markle sister samantha unannounced palace visit
story: Samantha Markle, , was locked in an embarrassing stand off with police guards as she tried to visit the Duchess of Sussex after their bitter fall out.But instead of a chance to speak to Meghan, the American tourist was forced to reluctantly leave a note with the guards for her estranged half-sister, the Sunday Mirror reports.Samantha arrived in London two weeks ago claiming she wanted to speak to her half-sister, who she hasn’t seen in more than a decade.A source told the newspaper: “This was a huge move on the part of Meghan’s sister to try to see her face to face and the fact she was turned away speaks volumes.Samantha later tweeted about the attempt to reconnect with her sister, writing: Everybody would love to know what’s in that letterSamantha first hit out at her famous half-sister after her romance with Prince Harry was revealed, branding her a social climber who is not fit to be a royal.She then announced that she would release her memoirs and that her sister should prepare herself for some home truths.But it was after she was snubbed from the wedding that things really turned sour and she has continued to vent her fury with frequent Twitter tirades.Samanthas representatives reportedly sent palace officials a letter demanding a meeting and giving them an ultimatum - arrange a face-to-face meeting with Meghan or she would show up on her doorstep.The source said: “She said words to the effect thatthe Palace didn’t do something to help mend the rt now, something may happen to their dad, who is in ill health.The ­suggestion was thatthe rt was left unhealed it would be their fault.“She went to the gates and tried to reason with them.She explained she had been in touch with palace ­officials and claimed they had ignored her advances, leaving her no choice but to arrive uninvited.Samantha, who suffers from multiple sclerosis, showed up a few days later with her partner, who pushed her wheelchair to the entrance of Kensington Palace.She was hopeful she would be let in but they turned her away and she handed one of the guards a letter for Meghan in the hope that it would get passed on, the source added.They then bizarrely went souvenir shopping and is said to have bought royal merchandise - including Meghan and Harry masks.During her UK visit, Samantha appeared on Jeremy Vine’s Channel  show where she defended her decision to criticise her half sister from dad Thomas first marriage.Samantha said: “I would just say that there’s so much water under the bridge and so much has spun out of control that was never intended to.“I think everybody was hurt at not being included or invited to the wedding.“I felt it could’ve all been nipped in the bud had everyone been included and we all agreed to move forward with positive resolve.“The hurt feelings wouldn’t have snowballed but, believe it or not, it doesn’t mean we don’t love you any less.“I just think that families can be this way when there’s confusion and when people are hurt.“So moving forward I apologise and I wish things could be dferent.”

title: prince harry us ambassador tom tugendhat
story: Rising star Tom Tugendhat suggested sending the royal to Washington DC as part of a post-Brexit diplomatic push.He told The Sun Harry could be ideal for the job because his we Meghan is American and he served with US troops in Afghanistan.Mr Tugendhat made the suggestion in an interview with the Atlantic magazine where he also called for the Government to create a super-department overseeing all foreign affairs.Askedhis call was sincere, the MP admitted the prince would probably prefer to stay out of politics.But he told The Sun: Im serious about using him better, and the US is an example of where that could happen.We could use someone like Harry, in somewhere like the US, to say - the UK is back.Having somebody who could really cut through would be one hell of an asset.He does have an American we, and he served alongside US forces. The idea of representing his country is something hes done a lot.Mr Tugendhat, who chairs the Commons powerful foreign affairs select committee, also suggested the job of ambassador to China could go to David Cameron.He added: The idea is that these arent quiet poistions any more.The MP insisted Britain needs to boost ambassadors public profile so that the rest of the world knows the UK is back as a global player.He said football stars and artists could also be signed up as diplomats - as long as they had an experienced deputy who could do most of the technical work.Mr Tugendhat has urged the PM to use Brexit as an opportunity to look outwards instead of becoming more closed to the world.

title: parliaments cleaners complain after they find vomit and used condoms in mp offices
story: Politicians were compared to rowdy freshers because of the disgusting mess they leave around the place.They will be spoken to by Commons staff and told to do a better job tidying up afterthemselves, the Sunday Times reported.A source told the paper: It’s the type of behaviour you would expect from students enjoying freshers’ week, not MPs and their staff.Cleaners are being confronted with vomit and used condoms in offices used by MPs and their staff.Most MPs share offices with their researchers and admin assistants.Those who work in Parliament face being asked to sign up to a code of conduct promising not to misuse the premises.The Commons drinking culture has come under scrutiny in the wake of the Pestminster scandal last year.Parliament hosts several cut-price bars and restaurants where MPs and their staff can often be seen drinking late into the night.One bar was temporarily shut last year after two workers had a massive fight.The authorities have since tried to crack down on drunken behaviour inside Parliament.A Commons spokesman said: The House of Commons provides offices to MPs and their staff to enable them to carry out their Parliamentary duties.Any use of such facilities must be in support of those duties, as specied in the Members’ Handbook and Code of Conduct. Any reported misuse of facilities will be taken seriously and investigated.

title: labour could back four day weeks for all workers john mcdonnell hints
story: The Shadow Chancellor said his officials are looking into the possibility of moving Britain to a four-day weekLabour takes power.The Tories accused the party of threatening untold damage to our economy by floating the radical policy.Labour are keen to improve workers productivity - meaning they could produce the same output in a shorter period of time.Mr McDonnell told the BBCs Sunday Politics: We will be exploring a whole range of issues about automation - we will look at the working week.Askedthat could include a four-day week, the Shadow Chancellor said: We have got to make sure in the fourth industrial revolution that workers get the benefits of this as well and that might be reducing hours of work.“We work the longest hours in Europe and yet we are less productive. The Germans and French produce in four days what we produce in five and yet we work the longest hours.Union bosses have previously backed the policy, which would potentially see workers earning the same in four days as they currently do in five.But the Tories today blasted Mr McDonnell for opening the door to the change.Party chairman Brandon Lewis said: Labour again looking to do untold damage to our economy, which would hurt our productivity, reduce living standards and create higher unemployment.

title: japan welcomes brexit britain into free trade zone
story: Japan’s premier Shinzo Abe described the UK as a country “equipped with global strength” as Theresa May bids to win over the EU on her Brexit plans.Mr Abe’s comments to the FT will also encourage Brexiteers as the PM has a week’s respite to sell Chequers at a crunch EU summit next week.The Cabinet are unlikely to move against her ahead of the meeting butit is again rejected by EU leaders she will be forced to come up with a Plan B.The TPP is a wide-ranging trade agreement between  Pacic countries, including Japan, Australia, Vietnam, Malaysia, Canada and Mexico.Trade Secretary Liam Fox held talks earlier this year with overseas officials about joining the TPP.If Britain joined, it could strike new deals with the countries which cover  per cent of the world’s economy.But it will only be possiblethe UK quits the EU’s customs union and wins the power to set its own tarfs.Quizzed on a Brexit deal between the UK and the EU, Mr Abe added: “I hope that both sides can contribute their wisdom and at least avoid a so-called disorderly Brexit.“I truly hope that the negative impact of Brexit to the global economy, including Japanese businesses, will be minimised.”He insisted the chances of getting the green light for a withdrawal treaty between Britain and the EU were “good”.He said: “The withdrawal treaty is already about  per cent agreed in terms of text, the issues that have not been signed off yet relate predominantly to Ireland.“The two negotiating teams need to lock themselves in a room for the next ten days or so.”Last night it emerged that ministers are in talks with as many as  Labour MPs to force through the Chequers Brexit deal.The Government’s whips’ office has made contact with the MPs as a back-up for when Mrs May’s Brexit deal is put to a vote in Parliament in early December.A source in the hardline ERG group told The Sun Theresa May was performing a “tricky balancing act” but could end up angering Tory MPs so much they would vote against the Government regardless.Last week Japanese trade official Taku Miyazaki, deputy director general of JETRO said Britain and Japan’s close relationship over the last four decades would stand in its favour.He said: “We don’t think that after Brexit the competitiveness, the characteristics of the UK will soon disappear.”Last month Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt delivered an impressive speech entirely in fluent Japanese during an official visit to Tokyo.He became the first UK minister to do so after living in Japan for  months as a student.Mr Hunt famously slipped up in July when he told a room full of Chinese leaders his we was from Japan – the land of their biggest rivals.The gaffe came on his first big foreign trip in the role as he was visiting Beijing. It was all the more embarrassing as the Foreign Secs we Lucia Guo is actually Chinese.The Cabinet Minister said: “My we is Japanese – er, my we is Chinese”, as he quickly corrected his “terrible mistake” and later took to Twitter to apologise “to the long-suffering Mrs H”.

title: john pop kennedy servedboer somme dunkirk in ww2
story: As they all sing lustily along with him to the words of the music hall classic I’m Not ­Particular, Kennedy and his men could have no idea of the ­horrors to come.Nor could he possibly foresee how he would later survive the slaughter of Gallipoli before being decorated for bravery on the most notorious killing fields of France and Flanders.Later, not even his we and family would know anything about his ­decision to join up again in  to fight the Nazis — aged  — before being evacuated amid the Miracle of Dunkirk.The incredible tale of courage is one of many being commemorated in the run-up to the th anniversary of the end of World War One on Armistice Day .Military historian and author Paul Reed said: “The story of Sergeant John Kennedy is a truly unusual and remarkable one.“The increased interest in the First World War has encouraged people to go up into their lofts and find ­diaries, photo albums and all sorts of treasures that have told us so much we didn’t know.”This is one of those extraordinary stories about an ordinary family man — my great grandfather “Pop”, an East London labourer who became a double world war hero.Born John Luke Kane on June , , he changed his name to ­Kennedy before joining the East Yorkshire Regiment in , aged . Brit troops were caught in a shooting galleryPosted overseas, Pop spent some time guarding the Empire in India before being transferred to Africa where his regiment served in both Sierra Leone and the bloody Boer War in South Africa.He was eventually discharged on histo England in . But following the outbreak of World War One, Kennedy immediately re-enlisted, leading men as a sergeant in  Battalionin their preparations.By July , the battalion had received the order to sail to the Aegean Sea to take on the Turks, who had sided with Germany.They headed for the peninsula of Gallipoli — a key Ottoman Empire stronghold — and straight into one of the greatest disasters in British ­military history.Exhausted by the beach landings at Suvla and being forced to march over rough ground in darkness for miles without water, Kennedy and his men in  Battalion were nevertheless then ordered to attack a ridge called Tekke Tepe as part of the ­catastrophic battle for Scimitar Hill.General Sir Ian Hamilton, ­Commander of the Mediterranean Expeditionary Force, had insisted that capturing Tekke Tepe was crucial to the success of the Gallipoli ­Campaign.As a sergeant following orders, Kennedy had been forced to drag his shattered and desperately thirsty men out of their trenches and into the face of the enemy.Kennedy had landed in the early hours of August  alongside  ­officers and  men. After three days of slaughter, his battalion had lost  officers and  men.In total, more than , troops died and , were wounded in the -month Gallipoli Campaign. Thousands were killed by disease.An unofficial history of the East Yorkshires says: “If ithad been held, the Gallipoli ­Campaign would have succeeded. The th East Yorkshires, who stormed the hill with limited support in dficult conditions were used inthe most important assault of the ­campaign.“They were bravely led and were ­decimated within sight of their ultimate objective.“The story of the th East Yorkshires at Tekke Tepe is not a particularly well researched or well understood part of the campaign, but it encapsulates everything in one small action that was wrong about Gallipoli.”Kennedy had been extraordinarily lucky to survive. But after a short ­period of recovery in Egypt, he and the rest of  Battalion were then thrust into some of the biggest and bloodiest battles in France and Belgium.In tiny, crabbed handwriting, his ­Soldier’s Paybook lists the scenes of slaughter that he incredibly survived, a litany of death — the Somme, Thiepval, Ypres, Messines, Lens and Loos and the Hindenburg Line. Kennedy and his ­Pioneers fought with distinction at the Battle of Flers-Courcelette, part of the First Battle of the Somme, where ,, men died, and where tanks were used for the first time.During  he served on the ­Hindenburg Line, digging forward trenches, often under heavy shelling from the Germans.As historian Everard Wyrall noted in his  book The East Yorkshire ­Regiment In The Great War, these men endured “days and hours spent in a spot where death may come”.Sergeant Kennedy wrote himself into Wyrall’s history with an astonishing act of bravery in June , which earned him the Distinguished Conduct Medal. Building a huge railway line to carry British guns towards the German trenches at Messines, the Pioneers came under heavy bombardment.Wyrall wrote: “All of these areas were under direct observation from the enemy’s lines and the work of the ­Pioneers was of a most trying nature. Shortly before the battle opened, about  yards of the railway was blown up by shell fire.“But a gallant corporal, with ten men, working from pm to am the next morning, succeeded in running up  truckloads of rail and material, every bit of which had to be unloaded and carefully concealed.”The railway line had been saved and the planned British offensive could begin.Wyrall’s description, taken from ­regimental war diaries, almost exactly matches Kennedy’s official citation for the DCM published in the London Gazette the following year.After a period of fighting and digging trenches at the Battle of Polygon Wood, the second Battle of Arras and at Lens and Loos, Kennedy was finally — after more than three years of service amid the slaughter — handed a typewritten note giving him orders toto Blighty.More than , British men had died on those blasted battlefields. Incredibly he had not been one of them. Most men would have been content to slip back into civilian le and do their best to forget the horrors of war. But Kennedy was not most men.When Britain declared war on ­Germany again in , the East ­Londoner went straight down to a local recruiting office in Leyton. Asked his age, he lied and said . In reality he was . He casually told his we Mab he was going away “for work”.He was signed to the Royal Fusiliers thBattalion, ­consisting of men aged  to , who had seen service in the Great War. The battalion left for France from ­Southampton early on February ,  on the SS Fenella, landing at Le Havre.Forming part of the th Brigade in the th Division, the nd Battalion moved into the Brussels area on May . On May , the Germans attacked and the blitzkrieg forced them back towards the French border and ­eventually to Dunkirk.A measure of the horrors which the men faced at Dunkirk is revealed in C Northcote Parkinson’s history of the regiment, Always A Fusilier.It tells how they were shelled ­repeatedly as they scrambled from the beach and waded chest-deep in ­seawater to reach some of the hundreds of “Little Ships” which had come to rescue them.Again, Kennedy — nearly four decades older than many of his comrades on those Dunkirk beaches — had defied all odds to survive. Arriving in Dover, he did not have a penny to his name and had to ask a shopkeeperhe could use his phone to let Mab know he was still alive.Earlier that day his son Jack had got married, not knowingPop was alive or dead. Dunkirk proved one campaign too many. Found out for being too old and declared “no longer required” by the Army, he went home to the relative peace of Walthamstow, this time for good, from where he watched Luftwaffe bombs fall on London during the Blitz.Historian Paul Reed said: “John ­Kennedy would have forged documents to show he was younger than he was to re-enlist.“If you were a recruiting sergeant major sitting at a table and a guy comes in with the Distinguished ­Conduct Medal, you think, ‘He’s going to be a really useful guy to have’.“He probably used the old trick of putting some boot polish in his hair to hide the grey. John’s battalion were in France to guard petrol depots, ammunition supply points and communications. They weren’t meant to be involved in the fighting.“He would have been part of an orderly withdrawal but when he got to Dunkirk, I would imagine someone like him is not just going to stand by and do nothing. The Miracle of Dunkirk was part of the propaganda of . John would have been a hero of Dunkirk in the eyes of the public.”After the war, Pop went back to labouring and was still working aged  in  when he tore a heart muscle lting a heavy ladder and died — a tragic end to a le of bravery and devotion to duty.There is one regret that hangs over this story, however. I never got to tell him what a hero he really was.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: hurricane michael florida state of emergency tropical storm michael
story: The storm is likely to make landfall in the US midweek and the National Hurricane Center has predicted it will upgrade to a hurricane as early as Monday night local time.The Miami-based weather centre said Tropical Storm Michael is getting stronger and the “threat to the Northeastern US Gulf Coast is increasing.It added in its pm BST bulletin: “Additional strengthening is expected during the next few days, and Michael is forecast to become a hurricane Monday night or Tuesday.”Florida Governor Rick Scott declared the state of emergency in  counties along the Panhandle and Big Bend coastal region to ensure there is ample time, resources and flexibility to get prepared.He said: This storm will be le-threatening and extremely dangerous.If this storm hit Panama City, Tampa could still have storm surge. Every family must be prepared.The governor was referring to two cities that are roughly  miles apart.He tweeted: “Our state understands how serious tropical weather is and how devastating any hurricane or tropical storm can be.As we continue to monitor this storm’s path toward Florida, it is critically important that our communities have every available resource to keep everyone safe.”Large swells, storm surges and isolated tornadoes are possible for the region.Scott said on Sunday night local time: “You can not hide from storm surge, so get prepared and get outevacuations are ordered.”Weather meteorologist Christopher Dolce said residents should begin preparing now.He said: “Interests in the Florida Panhandle should begin preparations and continue them into Tuesday morning.Hurricane conditions are possible in the region by Wednesday with damaging winds, dangerous storm surge, and heavy rain.Currently, the storm is about  miles South East of Cozumel, Mexico in the Yucatan Peninsula.Before hitting the US, Tropical Storm Michael will bring heavy rain and power outages to parts of the Yucatan Peninsula and Western Cuba.Accuweather Senior Meterologist Mike Doll said: “Through Monday, flooding rain is expected across far eastern portions of the Yucatan Peninsula and far western Cuba.”Michael is the th named storm of the  hurricane season, according to hurricane center spokesman Dennis Feltgen.

title: jean claude juncker everything wrong with eu
story: He is everything that’s wrong with the European project — and why it’s so vital that we leave.In his latest rant, he demanded “respect” and delivered a warning that “Press freedom has its limits”. Why Alas, Luxembourg’s finest is annoyed that the media keep reporting on the persistent rumours that he is half-cut most of the time.He must be to think, as he does, that the UK would have voted Remainonly HE had been involved in the referendum. Fat chance. He’d have doubled the Leave vote.The trials and tribulations of Brexit might have made some wonderit’s all worth the hassle. So it’s good of Jean-Claude, a puffed-up political pygmy, to remind us why we’re better off out.Brexiteers need to keep their eyes on the prize. Attention-seeking bores like Andrew Adonis and Alastair Campbell, plus shadowy campaign outfits, are trying their hardest to undermine Brexit.Nobody should think this battle is won. Nobody should be complacent about political battles still to come.And nobody who believes in a prosperous, independent nation should allow the perfect to be the enemy of the good when it comes to Britain’s departure, and walk into the Remainers’ “people’s vote” trap.We leave in less than six months. And when we do, we’ll raise a glass. Maybe Jean-Claude will join us.THE Universal Credit system IS a good idea – but the roll-out must be done properly.The Tories’ benefit changes in the last Government, making it more rewarding to be in work, are a big part of the ­reason employment is at a record high. UC is the final part of that puzzle.But reports that some working families could lose signicant amounts of cash overnight are deeply worrying.Our benefits regime needs to be firm.But it must also be fair.BOB Geldof warns Britain will be a ­“cultural jail” after Brexit.Quite why the power to strike our own trade deals will affect our ability to play guitar isn’t yet clear.In fact, when it comes to music, it’s Britain’s institutions that are more­ ­dangerous. The BBC has decided in its infinite wisdom to publish its entire archive of classical music to compete with streaming services and record labels. Why  Just because it can It’s a decision that sums up the big-state, God-complex thinking that seeps right through the BBC.Lord Hall promised to change Auntie’s tune – but he’s still hitting the wrong notesOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bob geldof rita ora no deal brexit letter
story: In a joint letter penned by the Boomtown Rats frontman, they claim the country would be placed in a “self-built cultural jail”.Addressed to Theresa May, they say Britain’s departure from the EU threatens the “vast voice” of the £. billion industry which “dominates” the market.Jarvis Cocker and Damon Albarn, the frontmen of Britpop bands Pulp and Blur, are also among the signatories as well as former Smiths guitarist Johnny Marr, Pink Floyd drummer Nick Mason and musical director of the London Symphony Orchestra Sir Simon Rattle.The letter said: “Imagine Britain without its music. If it’s hard for us, then it’s impossible for the rest of the world.“In this one area,nowhere , Britain does still rule the waves. The airwaves.“But Brexit threatens, as it does so much , this vast voice. This huge global cultural influencer.“We are about to make a very serious mistake regarding our giant industry and the vast pool of yet undiscovered genius that lives on this little island.”The Observer who published the letter said it was circulated by Sir Bob Geldof with the subject “towards a nd vote”, in which Mrs May is urged to note that Brexit will “impact every aspect of the music industry”.Quite why the power to strike our own trade deals will affect our ability to play guitar isn’t yet clear.In fact, when it comes to music, it’s Britain’s institutions that are more­ ­dangerous. The BBC has decided in its infinite wisdom to publish its entire archive of classical music to compete with streaming services and record labels. Why  Just because it can It’s a decision that sums up the big-state, God-complex thinking that seeps right through the BBC.Lord Hall promised to change Auntie’s tune – but he’s still hitting the wrong notes. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nicola sturgeon snp conference speech
story: The First Minister said she would “expect” her  MPs to get behind a vote on the final EU orce dealproposed in the Commons.But she warned she would seek assurances that Scotland’s decision would be respected.Speaking on the first day of her party’s conference in Glasgow, the SNP boss said: “We would not stand in the way of a second referendum, a so-called People’s Vote.“SNP MPs would undoubtedly vote for that proposition.“We would want to talk to people about how we ensure that Scotland does not end up in the same position all over again — where we voted to remain in the EU but find ourselves facing exit completely against our will.”Pressed on the issue on the BBC’s Andrew Marr Show, Ms Sturgeon added: “I would expect the SNP MPs to vote for thatthat comes to a vote in the House of Commons.”The SNP has previously ducked fully endorsing another referendum on quitting the EU.It said only that it would “not stand in the way” of one — suggesting the party could abstain in any Westminster vote.Some senior SNP figures have been wary of supporting the idea over fears Nats’ backing for any second Brexit vote could be used by pro-Union parties as a “precedent” for a rerunScotland ever backs independence.But the sht in stance came after a poll of Nats members found there was overwhelming support for a People’s Vote, with  per cent of respondents backing it and  per cent against.Ms Sturgeon also said her party would slap down any Brexit deal Theresa May strikes with Brussels unless it includes continued membership of the single market and customs union.She described indy as “inevitable” after we leave the EU as a Survation poll revealed by The Scottish Sun on Sunday suggested a   Yes No split in the event of No Deal.The First Minister also warned a “blind Brexit” — where MPs are forced to vote on a deal while the UK’s future relationship with the EU is still unclear — would be “almost as unacceptable as no deal at all”.She added it would lead to a “fire or frying pan” scenario.Ms Sturgeon confirmed she will set out her plans for IndyRef at “the end of this phase of the Brexit negotiations” — likely to be before Christmas.The party chief has been under mou­nting pressure from Nats hard­­liners who have accused her of dithering over the timing of another vote and want her to call one as soon as possible.On Saturday, one of the largest ever pro-indy demonstrations was held in Edinburgh, with tens of thousands of people taking place in an All Under One Banner march to the Scottish Parliament.The First Minister went on: “I think we are on a journey and that will end with Scotland becoming independent.”It came as Nats Westminster leader Ian Blackford said the SNP could only back a People’s Vote on Brexitthere was an assurance Scotland would not be forced to accept the resultit votes dferently from England and Wales.Two years ago, all  local authority areas north of the border rejected Brexit. Overall Scots voted  per cent to remain in the EU.Mr Blackford said: “We have to have the protection of knowing thatthe UK has a second vote and we end up in the same situation as we had in , we would be able to determine our own future. That would be only right and proper.”He added: “There has to be the right for Scotland to call a second referendum on independence.” But rivals last night united to slam the SNP’s stance.Tory constitution spokesman Adam Tomkins branded them “the party of neverendum” by signalling backing for a second Brexit vote while pushing for IndyRef.Prof Tomkins said: “Today we’ve learnt that, not content with taking Scotland backwards, Nicola Sturgeon’s made clear she wants to drag the entire UK through a second referendum on Brexit too.“Scotland voted to stay in the UK and the UK voted to leave the EU. Scotland has had enough of Nicola Sturgeon’s endless complaints and demands for a rematch.”CHANCER OF THE DAY: A photographer tried to get Nicola Sturgeon to put her “Stronger for Scotland” slogan into action by trying out a bench press at a fitness expo at the SEC. Her spin doctors politely declined.BLAST OF THE DAY: Conference chairman Derek Mackay angrily cut off serial conference stage-stormer Gerry Fisher — who accused party bosses of being liars — telling him: “This is not a point of order, this is out of order.”CRACKPOT OF THE DAY: MP Joanna Cherry annoyed party bosses by claiming independence could be declared without a referendum.She said: “There has to be a democratic event, and I choose those words wisely, it doesn’t have to necessarily be a referendum, it could be something , like a general election.”MISSING IN ACTION: TheSNP’s top Holyrood spin doctor Fergus Mutch has raised a few eyebrows by going on holiday over the conference — blaming a family wedding.Lib Dem boss Willie Rennie, whose party has been leading calls for a People’s Vote, accused Nats of a “shoddy exploitation of Europe” by using it to push their independence agenda.The North East Fe MSP said: “After months of dawdling and deflection when it comes to a People’s Vote, it’s finally all out in the open.“The SNP only want the public to have the final say on Brexitit’ll suit them. The First Minister cynically plots and calculates while the Brexit clock ticks.“When it counts Nicola Sturgeon is missing — just like Jeremy Corbyn. We can’t sit idly by and let this devastation go ahead.“The public deserves to have the final say on whether the Brexit deal is good enough.”Labour’s Ian Murray, a campaigner for Brexit vote No, hailed the pledge.The Edinburgh South MP said: “Nicola Sturgeon has been reluctant to back a People’s Vote, so her U-turn is welcome.“Given we know there are Tory MPs who will vote for a People’s Vote — and with Labour backing the option of a People’s Vote at its conference — we are now heading towards a parliamentary majority for it.”But he added: “Unfortunately, however, the SNP is still putting its obsession with independence ahead of the best interests of the country.”christine.lavelle@the-sun

title: vapers save thousands life insurance
story: A new comparison site for e-cigarette users will give them an option to save almost half of what they currently pay for le and critical illness insurance.Most insurance companies treat vapers the same as smokers and a -year-old smoker who takes out £, of le cover over  years, will pay around £. a month.That compares to a non-smoker who pays £. a month for the same level of cover. It follows a recent Public Health England report that found vaping was  per cent less harmful than smoking.MPs also recently recommended e-cigarettes be given out on prescription to help smokers stop the habit.The powerful Commons Science and Technology Committee said e-cigs were being “overlooked” as a stop smoking tool when nicotine patches and gum were given out by doctors on prescription.David Mead, chief executive of Future Proof Insurance who have launched the comparison website, said: “We wanted to bring an easy to use price comparison site to help vapers save money.“The biggest winners are people who have only been vaping and people who have not been using tobacco products for at least  months.”A spokeswoman from the UK Vaping Industry Association added: “This is fantastic news for vapers all across the UK who will finally be given fair treatment.“It is a great sign to see that one of the most risk adverse industries is finally acknowledging the health evidence and is moving away from treating vapers as smokers.”The Treasury had considered taxing vapers as Philip Hammond sought new funding to pay for an NHS cash bonanza but ruled it out following a backlash.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: adam marsh tatoo entry stamp che bar barnsley
story: Adam Marsh, , got the inking while boozed-up on holiday in Magaluf in tribute to his favourite hometown nightspot Che Bar in Barnsley, South Yorks.He paid  euros for his drunk doodling meaning he will only have to go to the £-entry club ten times to make the tattoo a worthwhile investment.Adam, who works as a baker, doesnt reckon he will have the tattoo long enough though and plans to get it covered up as soon as he can.Speaking of his tattoo, he said: I cant even remember getting it done, but I am known for being the joker of the group so Im sure I was up for it at the time.When I woke up and saw it I just screamed in madness at myself.I did get in for free though, as soon as we got home we went out and tried it.I actually worked at the bar for two years and used to get in for free, so now I feel like a VIP again.This wasnt the first time that Adam has woke up with tattoo shame, as he has seven more, including an ill-fated its coming home tattoo to show support to the England squad.Speaking of his plans for a coverup he said: Im definitely getting rid of it soon enough.I think Ive picked what I want to cover it with already and Im really going to try not get any daft tattoos again.People actually expect me to go on holiday and get some ridiculous tattoo now, Ive made it my thing worryingly.Adam has decided to cover the tattoo up with a bigger piece on his hand such as a rose or a skull which fully covers up his current tattoo.

title: cafe bristol sorry parents children leave
story: Cafe Walcot in Bath displayed the typed sign which said: You are entering a grown up zone.Cafe owner Debbie Still was horried when she saw the sign put up by one of her employees, Bristol Live reports.The staff member acted as a result of a group of children causing havoc.They took fruit from a bowl and threw it around the cafe, Mrs Still said.The notice was put up on Thursday, October  and instructed customers to take their business to another cafe in the citythey could not control their children.Mrs Still said the sign was removed as soon as she found out about it.She said: It was only up for ten minutes. I was very upset about it.It shouldnt have happened. Ive got three children so I understand what its like being a mum.She added: Weve created a nice, calm, really lovely space that we want everyone to enjoy, and we want customers to behave with consideration towards one another.The cafe owner has since insisted her cafe is both child and dog friendly and has apologised for the sign.Mrs Still says she understands the frustrations of her staff but their reaction was inappropriate.She said the person responsible has been reprimanded.A photo of the sign was posted on Twitter with the caption: Allegedly this has gone up in a new Bath cafe and people are losing their ish about it. Any truth in either  #BathLe.While many responded to the tweet expressing relief that a cafe free of unruly children might be available in the city, not everyone agreed.@LouiseCulmer wrote: Very rude. If true, I wouldnt set foot in the place.While @EmilyLauraVass tweeted: I have kids  not at all insulted. Sounds like heaven.One Twitter user didnt seem at all bothered by the content of the sign, just its missing apostrophe: Ive got more of an issue with that missing apostrophe than Ive ever had with other peoples children!Cafe Walcot, which opened on September , has issued this apology: Cafe Walcot management would like to apologise for the sign pictured in the foyer on Thursday morning.The wording on the poster was inappropriate, this was immediately pointed out and the sign removed.We deeply regret any offence caused and acknowledge the poor judgment shown in posting the sign in the first place.We strive to promote a positive and welcoming environment at Cafe Walcot and this was not in keeping with this ethos.

title: theresa may brexit chequers eu summit
story: The PM is being squeezed on all sides as she has just nine days to lock down her Brexit plan.But she insisted the ball is still in Brussels court - saying Eurocrats need to compromise ahead of a crunch summit next week.EU officials declared over the weekend that the two sides are  per cent of the way to securing a deal.But Westminster insiders have said Mrs May must endure a hell week as she tries to pin down the final ten per cent.And the PMs spokesman warned today that a deal was not yet guaranteed.He said: We have always said that we are working hard for a deal this autumn and that continues at pace.Its worth me pointing out that there is a dference between people talking optimistically about a deal, and a deal actually being agreed.There remain big issues to work through and, as the PM has said, this will require movement on the EU side.The spokesman insisted Mrs May wont sign up to a blind Brexit, which would see us quit the EU in March without having a detailed agreement on the future trade deal between Britain and Europe.If the EU summit next week goes as badly as last months gathering in Salzburg, backbench MPs will ramp up their efforts to get Mrs May to dump the plan altogether.Tory Brexiteers warned today that the Irish backstop - a proposal to keep Britain in the customs unionthere is no other solution to the Irish border problem - must expire by .Otherwise Britain will be tied to the EU indefinitely and will not really have left, MPs told The Times.The PM is hoping to sign off on a draft agreement when she meets European leaders in Brussels next Wednesday.The deal could then be confirmed at a special summit scheduled for next month.Mrs May will make her case to the Cabinet tomorrow, where some senior ministers are expected to demand that she prepare a Plan B forChequers collapses next week.One source told the Daily Mail: If there is another Salzburg-style rejection at the summit then things will start to get fruity.Eventhe PM does cut a deal with the EU, she faces a tricky time getting it through the CommonsBut even anti-Corbyn Labour figures have rejected the idea of propping up the Tories in power.And Tory Brexiteers say Mrs May risks a huge backlashshe continues to pursue the tactic.Stewart Jackson, former chief of staff to David Davis, warned last night: This is a waste of time.These Labour MPs won’t prop up a Conservative Government but the tactic will alienate many more Conservative MPs and members.

title: coal chiefs plotted delay compensation
story: NewsCoal chiefs plotted to "delay" compensation from miners dying from lung diseasesEXCLUSIVE: British Coal memos reveal plans to make it “costly and ­unattractive” for miners and families to pursue claims - with many eventually winning a payout only after deathShareCommentsByNick SommerladJonny Jacobsen:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsCoal Miners ing to the surface after finishing the day sht at Maltby Pit in  "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPit bosses plotted to “delay” payouts to tens of shythousands of miners dying from lung diseases. Newly-discovered memos from British Coal reveal plans to make it “costly and shyunattractive” for miners and their families to pursue claims. More than , ex-miners eventually won damages in the pound.billion fight, but the process, involving a y High Court case, was dragged out for decades and the final claim was not settled until . More than half of claims were paid to families of miners who had already died. Solicitor Gareth Morgan, of law firm Hugh James, involved in the compensation fight from the start, said: “This memo explains their decision to fight everything.” The first British Coal memo, dated May  , and sent to executives, admits it had probably failed to defeat the miners’ claim that coal dust caused respiratory problems.  The aim now was to “minimise liability” by trying to blame some of the miners’ problems on smoking. A second memo, dated July , , for the Department of Trade and Industry and the Treasury, set out tactics to limit costs. These included “delay” and “making shylitigation costly and unattractive”. In January , the High Court ruled that British Coal’s predecessor, the National Coal Board, put production before safety, leaving many miners with respiratory diseases.

story: NewsLabour could bring in a four-day working week hints Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell"The Germans and French produce in four days what we produce in five"ShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsCould Britain radically change tack - and back a four-day working week  "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabour could bring in a four-day working weekJeremy Corbyn wins power, a top ally has hinted. We will look at the working week because I think people are working too long.  Asked directlythis could mean a four day week is in the manesto, he said: We will see how it goes. I went to a school play where when of the children in the play said to their parents, I never see you because you pass in the night on dferent shts. It breaks down family le. title: 5500 brit troops high tech
story: News, Brit troops high-tech war games in the desert go on from dusk till dawnEXCLUSIVE: Elaborate training push in the hostile environment in the Omani desert involved  armoured vehicles, six warships and eight Typhoon fightersShareCommentsByDan Warburton:,  OCT NewsA joint operation between British and Omani forces in the desert is helping the UK prepare for conflict "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDeep in the dust and sand of the Omani desert, Britain is training for war at am. Monstrous tanks and other vehicles churn up billowing clouds as they rumble along in searing -degree heat. Infantrymen in full combat gear shyswtly deploy to face the “enemy”. At sea a huge Navy task force has entered Omani waters while RAF jets have made their way to the Gulf State. This week the Sunday People joined the Armed Forces in Oman on the shybiggest UK military exercise in  years. Named Sa Sareea , or Swt Sword , it involves , British personnel,  armoured vehicles, six warships and eight Typhoon fighters.  War games in one of the world’s harshest environments have one motive – to ensure the UK is battle-ready to join international allies to tackle threats posed by the likes of Russia and ISIS. Strategists are mimicking so-called “peer-plus” military heavyweights – like Vladimir Putin’s army – so they can counter the world’s most elite forces. From Goodall Garrison at Camp Shafa, Brigadier Zac Stenning, commander of  UK Armoured Infantry Brigade, said: “We face many threats, this is an uncertain world. “As the Army, we want to be able to offer choices to our political leaders and UK citizens that we are capable of acting.  “It’s very hard to predict where the next crisis is but we want to ready for it. We train our army for a iety of dferent threats across the world.” The joint operation with the Omani forces comes as the UK faces a growing threat from Russia in the wake of the Novichok poisoning scandal. Earlier this year our Services head, Chief of the Defence Staff General Nick Carter, said Putin’s forces were the biggest threat to our way of le in years. This week a four-strong Russian hacking team was arrested outside the world’s chemical weapons watchdog in Holland — while attempting to sabotage the Salisbury probe. And while Britain wages information warfare on the Kremlin, Brigadier Stenning, the commander of  UK Armoured Infantry Brigade, said the military was keeping its eyes “wide-open” to a number of global threats.  He said: “This is an exercise in facing what we call a ‘peer plus’ opponent, rather than lesser opponents. “We are trying to put ourselves against those that might be the best equipped, those that might have the best training and those who would give us our toughest challenge. “Over the last two years we have looked at dferent threat vectors. We are growing more confident about how we might seek to confront and take down those threats as they come towards us. “You have heard the Chief of the Defence Staff speak quite publicly now about the threat from Russia. That is a pacing threat and he has publicly stated that. We keep our eyes wide open. “The fact is the world’s very uncertain, there are a lot of threat vectors.  “We have threats from Syria, there are crises in Africa, not necessarily purely military, as you saw British defence respond to Ebola. “There are many challenges out there that we have got to be capable of responding to.” The month-long war game in Oman will include training rapid reaction forces to deploy in crisis zones around the worldconflict is on the brink of erupting. And they are working on high-tech strike brigades designed to practice st-century warfare, using advanced technology to topple enemies. The Sunday People rolled out with the Mercian Regiment as they began the huge training exercise.  In the dead of night the awesome array of armoured vehicles including Warriors, Bulldogs and Trojans, thundered into le. We also joined the Royal Tank Regiment’s Cyclops squadron in staging war games over huge swathes of desert. Around eight miles from Camp Shafa, platoon commander Lieutenant Niall O’Malley Pearson led an attack on the “enemy” – represented by the Household Cavalry set up in a formation typically used by Putin’s forces. Lt Pearson, , rounded three Warriors before speeding across the dust and sending sand spilling into the air. And after calling “Release, release, release” on the radio a fourth vehicle thundered through the middle of the unit to attack an “enemy” Russian T tank.  Lt Pearson said: “When I give the ‘Release’ order, it’s brilliant, it’s like releasing a pack of dogs.” The military outfit will travel  miles from the camp, at the base of the Jebel mountains near the capital Muscat, across the desert to a finish point near Duqm Port. Meanwhile Armed Forces Minister Mark Lancaster said the relationship with the Omani forces was important as “violent extremist organisations seek to undermine stability”. He told sailors and Royal Marines assembled on the deck of the amphibious carrier HMS Albion it proved they were able to deploy anywhere in the Gulf “ the situation demands it”.

title: beluga whale benny lost thames
story: NewsBeluga whale Benny lost in Thames could be rescued in Free Willy style operationThe same methods which were used to lt and fly Keiko - the whale which starred in the blockbuster movie Free Willy - are being prepared by animal welfare expertsShareCommentsByAndy Lines:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsBenny the beluga has captured the hearts of Londoners - and others worldwide "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe beluga whale “lost” in the Thames estuary could be rescued in a “Free Willy style” operation by being flown back to Iceland. Animal welfare experts are preparing to use the same methods which were used to lt and fly Keiko - the whale which starred in the film Free Willy. Benny the Beluga has been seen in the Thames over the past ten days. But experts fear he could need moving back to the colder waters off Icelandhe is still in the same area in the spring. If necessary next year they will lt Benny in a giant “wet sling” before transferring him to a tank and flying him  miles to a sea sanctuary off Iceland. Dr Chris Parsons, a marine biologist who has been in touch with those monitoring Benny’s health, said: “In the long termthis animal starts failing, what they could do is move him or her to an interim facility in one of the sea le centres, then move it to the beluga whale sanctuary. “Maybe it’ll be OK over winter, but when it comes into next summer andthere’s yet another heatwave, that will not be great for this animal. The water temperature is too warm.  “To come into the Thames is really rather odd and of course there are concerns about pollution and whether it would pick up a disease.” But for the moment Benny the beluga will remain in the Thames unhindered, unless it begins to show signs of ill health or distress. Benny would be rehomed in a huge pen in Klettsvik Bay in an operation that would mirror the one mounted when Keiko, a ,lb killer whale, was flown from an aquarium in Newport, Oregon, to a tiny coastal Icelandic island. British Divers Marine Le Rescue, the team charged with taking care of Benny, confirmed they were considering proposals to eventually move the whale.

story: NewsHuman race faces extinctionmale sperm count continues to fall worldwideSperm quality is reducing by % per year according to a study of , men visiting fertility clinics in Europe and the USA - with experts blaming chemicals and modern lestylesShareCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science Correspondent:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video meet-man-super-sperm-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMale fertility is falling every year in the Western world — and experts blame chemicals and modern lestyles. A study of , men visiting fertility clinics in Europe and the USA found sperm quality reducing by almost % per year. Separate research focusing on , sperm donors [men with above-normal fertility] showed a similar pattern. While most men can still father a child, scientists say the human race faces extinctionthe trend continues. It follows a landmark study last year showing a % cut in Western sperm counts from  to .  Pesticides, hormone-disrupting chemicals, stress, smoking and obesity are seen as causes, along with too much alcohol, caffeine and processed meat. The chemicals include some used to make plastics flexible and furniture flame-retardant – which can enter the food chain via plants or animals. Experts also blame increases in testicular cancer, the number of boys born with one or both testicles missing, and changing testosterone levels. Scientists in Valencia, Spain,and New Jersey, USA, carried out the first large-scale study of “swimming” sperm, known as the total motile sperm count.

How can they put a price on a relationship  You cant help who you fall in love with. Its really worrying
