story: NewsMum relives cradling dying best friend in her arms after being butchered by ex on school runEXCLUSIVE: Brave Sallie Clarke desperately tried to save her best friend, Emma Day, after she was stabbed to death by her ex-boyfriendShareCommentsByLiz Dunphy:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video best-friend-describes-horrying-last-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSallie Clarke remembers every day how her best friend died in her arms after being butchered on the school run by her ex. Drenched in blood Sallie cradled mum-of-two Emma Day in the street, comforting her in her final moments, as she took her last breath. Moments earlier brave Sallie had desperately tried to fight off Emmas freakily calm ex, Mark Morris, as he repeatedly stabbed her in a row over child support after chillingly telling her Ill go to prison before you get a penny from me. Sallie then battled in vain to save Emmas le with CPR. Sallie, , said: He came flying past. I saw this shimmer, I clocked he had a kne. He just shoved the kne into Emmas back. I ran between him and Emma and did everything I could to fight him off. Dad who said Im really sorry to six-year-old daughter before stabbing her mum to death is jailed for leEmma turned and said what the f**k  I managed to get him off of her. He was coming either side of me with this kne. I just had to get him off her. I couldnt think about anything . I was screaming at him to stop, screaming for help, but he was totally silent. He was freakily calm. He was stabbing the mother of his child but he was calm. He looked like any other time I saw him. He didnt look angry or upset. He got a couple of slashes in and stabbed her one more time before I managed to get him off of her. I pushed him, he fell on the ground and then he ran away up the road. Emma then collapsed on the floor and there was blood everywhere. I was trying to stop the bleeding. Two people came out when they heard me screaming and tried to help. I called . The ambulance lady was telling me what to do for Emma. I was screaming at Emma not to leave, stay with me Emma, stay with me Emma. “I just had to keep her alive for her kids. Thats all that was going through my head. I have to keep her alive. She cannot die. He cannot kill her. Shes too young to die. Dad who said Im really sorry to six-year-old daughter before stabbing her mum to death is jailed for leMorris, , was sentenced to le in prison, to serve at least  years, for the attack in May last year. Hospital administrator Emma, , had asked Mark to pay pound,-a-year in child support for their six-year-old daughter after the couples eight-year relationship ended in . But Mark refused and repeatedly sent her threatening text messages, claiming he would kill himselfEmma did not cancel her child maintenance claim. Before the murder, he had researched ways online to kill himself, said goodbye to his work colleagues and told his daughter she would not see him again. And that morning, he sent Emma a text message about a grand finale before waiting outside the gates of their childs school, armed with the kitchen kne he would use to kill her. Every time you close your eyes you see the incident. Its like a video playing in your head, over and over again, said Sallie. “Mark was asked to pay pound a day in child support. He left his daughter with no mum and no dad for pound per day. “And he planned it. He took the kne with him from his own kitchen and he told his mum what he was going to do.” On that fateful day Emma had asked Sallie to walk her and the kids home because she was scared of what Morris might do. When he approached them Sallie sent Emmas two children back to her home along with her two kids. Sallie said: “Mark said he couldnt afford child support. We were there for about  minutes arguing. He was really irate and drunk but Emma stood her ground. She said she needed help with his child.With the amount of blood I knew it was serious. The ambulance people were going to operate on her on the road, they had to open my friend up on the concrete.  “But youre still telling yourself shes going to get through this. I didnt know at that stage he had punctured her heart. “They told me the last thing to go was her hearing. So she knew I was with her. She wasnt on her own. The first kne wound was the one that killed her because he got her heart then he stabbed her another four times. I overheard the ambulance man saying she was dead just as Marks mum turned up. She was crying and screaming. More than a year on Sallie is still haunted by the murder. Every single day theres something to remind me of her. For six months I couldnt go into the kitchen and chop anything with a kitchen kne. It was too much. The shower hitting my face reminded me of blood spattering on me. Just walking out the door, people walking around, you just want to scream, do you know whats happened  Its affected everything. Six years earlier and Emma and Mark had celebrated the happy news that Emma was pregnant with their first child together. It was a whirlwind romance after the pair met at a mutual friends BBQ.  Sallie recalls: They had some conversations and exchanged numbers but she wasnt overly interested at first. He seemed shy, she had her older son to think about and she wasnt long out of a relationship. But then they got together and he moved in pretty quick. I did think Mark was a bit strange, kind of moody. We both wonderedthey were moving too fast but I think living at Emmas was convenient for Mark. Then he lost his job at an Asda supermarket and it was all on Emma. They started arguing after that and he moved out. But they got back together, everything was good for a while. She was in love with him at the begining. There were a few things she didnt like about him but she just put that down to normal relationship stuff. But when Emma fell pregnant Morris became increasingly controlling and violent. It wasnt planned but Emma was very happy about it, said Sallie. She called me and said: You wont believe this but Im pregnant! Were pregnant at the same time! I laughed when she said it, I was pregnant with my second child at the time too. Mark was shocked but seemed happy that they were having a baby. But once she was pregnant he became very controlling. He was very controlling over her older child too and he was scared of him. Mark got increasingly controlling and moody and they had a few fights. He would constantly criticise her parenting of her older child. Hed say his child would never behave like this or that. When she had their child he was extremely controlling over that child too. Emma couldnt leave the child with anyone, he had to be there.  If she was out, he would message her  -  times over the space of an hour. Hed put her down, criticise her parenting, call her a selfish mum, and shed rush home. Id try to stop her but you have to let people do what they want to do. He had to know where Emma was, what time she was coming back, who she was with. Emma became distant from her family and stopped socialising with her friends, you couldnt really go to her house much anymore. In one sense it raised alarm bells but I thought theyre trying to make a family, everyones finding their feet, give them space. But when Emma started telling me and two other friends about his controlling behaviour, we told her she had to put a stop to it. He made comments about her being stupid, saying that she needed to be told what to do and couldnt make decisions for herself. Her confidence went really low as time went on. There were a few incidents where he had shoved her, and another incident that she reported to the police where he had pinned her to the bed and had bruised her arms. The last two years of her le she was pretty scared of him, and what he was capable of. He tried to pick up the kids from my house smelling of drink and turned up at school drunk to pick up his child. Emma got an injunction after that to stop him going near the kids or her.  He listened to it at first but then he would send six, seven, eight abusive text messages and voicemails daily, threatening her. She showed them to the police. Mark thought he was very intelligent. He could word things so it didnt come out like he was threatening her le but he would manipulate her by saying that he would take his own leshe didnt do what he wanted. Despite Marks abusive behaviour, Sallie said that Emma still wanted their daughter to maintain a relationship with her dad and his family. She would still drive the little one to his mums house to see him. He would then ask his daughterEmma was with anyone , and badmouth her to their child. Money was tight so Emma applied for child support. Thats when Mark got really vicious, he started hanging around the property and their childs school and the police were called several times about him but he had always left by the time police got there. Four days before he killed her, she texted me and said Mark was threatening her and her older child and threatened to take her younger child away. When I spoke to her she was crying. She said I think he might hurt me. As well as Sallie being left scarred from the events of that day, both her children have also suffered and are currently on waiting lists for counselling to help them. She said: My daughters have been on waiting lists since it happened. Theyre both emotional wrecks and really anxious. My youngest is scared to go to sleep and doesnt want to leave me. Shes up until am or am every night. If they got help when it happened they could be ok but now theyre not. And Sallie is plagued by questions about how Emmas death could have been avoided. I wish Emma had stayed in my house that day. If she had not gone around that corner she would still be here.

title: pilot answers questions every terrified
story: NewsPilot answers all the questions every terried flier wants to know - from turbulence to landingNervous passengers may find themselves consumed by anxiety and questions in the lead-up to flights - below, a pilot provides some answersShareCommentsBySteffan RhysSophie Evans:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT News" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _A-pilot-answers-all-the-questions-nervous-flyers-could-ever-want-to-ask.jpg" Some nervous fliers may wonder whether passengers can be sucked out of a plane window"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFor some, flying can be a terrying experience. From turbulence fears to concerns about landing, these passengers can find themselves consumed by anxiety in the lead-up to flights. They may question how likely their plane is to crash, what would happenan engine failed, and whether a bird strike could be dangerous. They might even wonder whether another flier could break a window - andso, whether everyone would then be sucked out of the aircraft.And they may also fear the consequences of passengers leaving their phones on during take-off and landing, Wales Online reports. But how can anxious fliers ever know the answers to these for sure  Wales Online asked Patrick Smith - a US-based airline pilot and the host of www.askthepilot -  questions passengers may want to know. Some parts of the following answers are drawn from his book, called Cockpit Confidential: Everything You Need to Know About Air Travel.You can buy the book here .. Can turbulence ever be dangerous  It’s exceptionally rare for an airplane to suffer structural damage from rough air. That said, severe turbulence encounters occasionally cause injuries. Almost always, however, this is a result of passengers not having their seat belts fastened when they should. It stands to reason that as climate change intensies certain weather patterns, we’ll be seeing an uptick in unusually strong turbulence. Run-of-the-mill turbulence, meanwhile, although it can be annoying and uncomfortable, is rarely,ever, dangerous. When I began fielding questions from the travelling public, I was startled to discover how many people were terried by even mild turbulence. From a pilots perspective, rough air is by and large a comfort and convenience issue. Its annoying, but its not going to flip the plane upside-down or result in any of the catastrophic scenarios nervous fliers are prone to imagine. This gets into something that I call “passenger embellishment factor,” or PEF. That’s my term for people’s tendency to exaggerate the sensations of flight. The altitudes, speeds and angles you perceive often arent close to the real thing. During turbulence, for example, many people believe that an airplane is dropping hundreds of feet at a time, when in reality, even in relatively heavy turbulence, the displacement is seldom more than  feet or so – the slightest twitch on the altimeter. Related video: What its like to be a long-haul pilot  . Why do they tell you to turn your phone off during take-off and landing  What happensyou leave your phone on  Its unlikely that a mobile phone can cause problems in the cockpit, particularly on modern aircraft where components are, by design, carefully shielded, but its not impossible. I’d guess at least half of all phones, whether inadvertently or out of laziness, are left on during flight. That’s about a million phones a day in the United States. If indeed this was a recipe for disaster, I think we’d have more evidence by now. That said, phones may have had a role in at least two serious incidents. The key word there is “may”, as interference can be impossible to trace or prove. Some blame a phone for the unsolved crash of a regional plane in Switzerland in , claiming that spurious transmissions confused the plane’s autopilot. Interference also was cited as a possible factor in a fatal crash in New Zealand in . Ultimately, though, the phone thing is more of a social issue rather than a technological one. That is, do you really want to be sitting on an airplane listening to  people chatting away simultaneously  It’s possible that airlines are using the mere possibility of technical complications as a means of avoiding the social implications of allowing cellular conversations on planes. The minute regulators say that phones are safe, a percentage of fliers will demand the right to use them, pitting one angry group of travellers against another.  . What would happenthe landing gear didn’t come down when you were landing  Landing gear mals are pretty far down the hierarchy of things a pilot might worry about. If something is going to go wrong with your plane, the landing gear is one of the least hazardous places for it to happen. The one exception to this would be the possibility of tyre failure or fire following a high-speed take-off abort, but otherwise gear problems are pretty easy to manage. The absolute worst-case scenario would be a failure of the gear to deploy at all, in which case you’d make a more or less normal landing on the plane’s belly. There’d be a slight chance of rupturing a fuel tank, but with the emergency apparatus only a few feet away even this would be a relatively minor hazard. Flight attendant racially abused by passenger on Southwest Airlines flight - all because of a simple request . Could a passenger break a plane window and would everyone get sucked outthat happened  Those windows are a lot stronger than they might seem. If a window were to break, whether through accident or because of some intentional act, the plane would decompress very quickly. It’s possible, though unlikely, that somebody could be sucked through the hole in the initial seconds afterward, but it would not be the Hollywood-style catastrophe that people are prone to imagine. . Is it safe to fly during a storm  What happensthe plane gets hit by lightning  Using onboard radar, along with help from air traffic control and other flights aloft, pilots avoid thunderstorms the way ships avoid icebergs. Still, lightning strikes happen on occasion, and airplanes are designed accordingly. The energy does not travel through the cabin electrocuting the passengers it is discharged overboard, partly through discharge wicks along the trailing edges of the wings and tail, nine times in ten, leaving little or no evidence of the strike itself. Once in a while theres damage, most commonly to the planes electrical systems. In  lightning caused a wing explosion aboard a Pan Am . Afterwards, the FAA mandated several new protective measures, including fuel tank modications and the installation of those discharge wicks. That was over  years ago and I know of no other lightning-related disasters to date.  . What’s the scariest thing that’s happened to you while flying  The scariest thing that ever happened to me was a near midair collision. I was  years old at the time and flying a four-seat private plane. We were operating under “visual flight rules” in uncontrolled airspace. The fact this was so long ago, and that it involved only a small plane in comparatively primitive circumstances, should underscore the safety of commercial flying. I’ve been an airline pilot since  and, accounting for that entire span of time, not a single instance of fright jumps to mind. . What happensthe engine fails  All commercial jets are certied to fly with an engine failed. More than that, every airliner must be capable of accelerating and climbing away, even with total failure of an engine on takeoff. This guarantee extends beyond the airport perimeter to account for buildings, mountains, TV antennae and whatever . Data are computed prior to every departure to assure the ability to safely climb and avoid any nearby obstructions. Airport elevation, runway , and the weather all are factors. With shorter runways, high temperatures, or in mountainous terrain, this will sometimes entail a weight penalty.  . How likely is a plane to crash  Let me answer this way: the past decade has been the safest in commercial aviation history. The year , in fact, goes down as the safest on record. For a point of comparison, go back and take a look at the year , when, worldwide, major aviation accidents killed almost , people. That included two of historys ten deadliest disasters happening within two months of each other! The s, s and s were an era re with horric crashes, bombings, airport attacks and so on. Large-scale disasters have become a lot less frequent. If it seems like more planes are crashing, that perception is largely the result of the media and its relentless fixation with even minor mishaps, compounded by the effects of social media. In decades past there was no   news machine to feed, spread across multiple s and starving for sensationalist fodder. . How do you become a pilot  Historically, most airline pilots earned their wings and built experience in the armed forces. Nowadays, however, a majority of pilotscome up through civilian channels. It’s a long and very expensive process that involves the slow accumulation of flight hours along with the requisite licenses and ratings. Once you’ve got the necessary experience, you’ll typically start your airline career at one of the regional carriers. Very few pilots go straight to a major carrier. This is changing, though, as a growing number of airlines turn to so-called “ab-initio” programs, whereby select pilots are groomed and trained by a carrier from the ground up, so to speak, with no prior experience. Ab-initio programs are rare in North America, but increasingly common where.  . Is there a period of time where you’re a “learner” pilot and you’re being taught in the cockpit  After completing classroom and simulator training on a particular aircraft, pilots will fly under the tutelage of a training captain for a certain number of hours. This takes place in normal revenue operations, with passengers on board. . How much does a computer fly a plane and how much do you fly a plane  Cockpit automation, and how pilots interact with that automation, is the single most exaggerated and misunderstood topic in all of commercial aviation. People have a vastly, vastly exaggerated sense of what an autopilot is, and what it’s capable of. Its true that pilots have come to rely on a somewhat dferent skill set. Seat-of-the-pants talents are a smaller part of the job than they were in decades past. Still, even the most routine flight is subject to countless contingencies and a tremendous amount of input from the crew.You will sometimes hear, for example, how pilots spend just three minutes actually piloting their plane over the course of the typical flight. Statements like this, which appear all the time, are highly deceptive. What they’re trying to say is that pilots nowadays spend a relatively brief amount of time with their hands physically on the control column or stick .That does not mean we arent controlling the airplane throughout the entire flight. Cockpit automation is not flying the plane. The pilots are flying the plane through the automation . The crew still needs to tell it what to do, when to do it, and how to do it. There are, for example, no fewer than six dferent ways that I can set up an “automatic” climb or descent on the Boeing that I fly, depending on circumstances. On any flight there are periods of high workload, and periods of low workload, but you’d be surprised how busy a cockpit can become - to the point of task-saturation - with the autopilot on .A comparison between flying and medicine is maybe the best one: modern technology helps a pilot fly a plane the way it helps a surgeon perform an operation. A jetliner can no more fly itself than an operating room can remove a tumor or perform an organ transplant by itself. Meanwhile, more than % of landings, and a full % of takeoffs are performed manually, hands-on, with either the captain or the first officer at the controls. . Have you ever seen another plane nearby and thought it was too close  Getting back to the earlier question, only one, when I was a private pilot in a four-seater. Passengers often misconstrue the distances between planes. This is another example of PEF. While we were flying to Paris, somebody will recall excitedly. Another plane passed so close to us, you could see the people inside!” While landing on parallel runways or crossing perpendicularly at high altitudes, airliners often pass within close proximity. But close proximity, in the doings of air traffic control, is measured in miles, or in thousands of feet. During cruise, vertical separation is never less than a thousand feet. To an anxious flier, distances and sensations are distorted. Planes are big, and yes, a  zooming past you, a thousand feet above or below, appears to be very close. But trust me, you have never, ever been remotely close enough to another plane to see faces through those small oval windows. . Why do all planes always fly at, feet Typical cruising altitudes y from , feet through , feet, give or take. The altitude you’re assigned depends on air traffic control constraints and, of course, the capabilities of the aircraft. Every aircraft type has a maximum allowable altitude. Generally, the higher you go, the less fuel you burn. But only to a point, and just because a plane can cruise at , feet doesn’t mean that it will do so every flight. Air traffic control might have other ideas in mind, and or the plane might be too heavy. We will sometimes “step climb” to a more efficient altitude as fuel is burned off. . Whats it like flying through clouds or in the dark when you can’t see anything in front of you  It’s dark and you can’t see anything in front of you. . Are bird strikes dangerous  Bird strikes are very common and rarely harmful — unless you’re talking from the bird’s point of view. I should hardly have to mention, however, that strikes are occasionally hazardous, such as when US Airways flight  went gliding into the Hudson River after both engines failed following a collision with a flock of geese. Modern turbofans are resilient, but they don’t take kindly to the ingestion of foreign objects, particularly those slamming into their rotating blades at high speeds. Birds don’t “clog” an engine but can bend or fracture the internal blades, causing power loss. The heavier the bird, the greater the potential for harm. Flying at  knots — in the United States, that’s the maximum allowable speed below , feet, where most birds are found — hitting an average-sized goose will subject a plane to an impact force of over , pounds. Your next question, then, is why aren’t engines built with protective screens in front  Well, in addition to partially blocking the inflow of air, the screen would need to be largeand incredibly strong. Should it fail, now you’ve got a bird and pieces of metal going into the motor. The incidents above notwithstanding, the vast improbability of losing multiple engines to birds renders such a contraption impractical.

title: take look inside englands smallest
story: NewsTake a look inside England’s smallest school thats only got SIX pupils and one full-time teacherThe miniscule Milburn School in Cumbria only uses one classroom and employs one full-time teacherShareCommentsByLaura Forsyth:,  OCT NewsPictured from left to right is teacher Hayley Dixon, headteacher Nick Page, teaching assistant Jessica White with the kids "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email England’s smallest school has been revealed...and it’s only got six pupils. Tiny Milburn School in Cumbria only has one classroom and just one full-time teacher .The school is so small, three-year-olds learn alongside ten-year-olds and their lunches are cooked by a local pub chef. Pupils play on the picturesque village green during breaks because there is no playground. And residents in the medieval village of Milburn, on the edge of the North Pennines Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty, are invited to take part in Sports Day in order to boost numbers.  The Christmas nativity play is also tricky, as there aren’t enough pupils and staff to take all the parts. In the rural setting, the children often have to stop playing as tractors pass by and there are no fences surrounding the small single building. There have been a number of attempts made to close the school - all of which have been vigorously opposed by the village. In , it had  pupils but numbers dropped as low as three in  following a dip in population in the hamlets surrounding Milburn. But despite its rural setting, the Church of England school is packed full of technology, including VR goggles and there are more laptops than there are pupils. Alongside lessons in the classrooms, pupils also enjoy the freedom of learning outdoors in their forest school.  The children - aged from three to ten years old - are often taught together in one group. Headteacher Nick Page says that the low number of students means they benefit from one-to-one teaching. He said: “Milburn is very special school in terms of its location, its number of pupils and what it has to offer. Hayley Dixon, , - the only full-time teacher - joined the school in September. She said: “I enjoy the flexibility that it has to offer and being able to go with things that are happening in the village.” Mr Page, , previously worked in an inner-city school in Brixton, south London, and now champions small schools. An Ofsted report in  - when Milburn had  pupils - ranked the school overall as ‘good”, noting that pupil’s development and welfare was “outstanding.” Since becoming executive headteacher in July, Mr Page is confident that the school will further improve. He splits his time as head between Milburn School and nearby Beaconside Primary School, which has  pupils.  Every Wednesday, the six pupils travel to his other school, in Penrith, a  minute drive away. There they benefit from specialist sports coaching, religious education, French and music lessons. The students adapt quickly to le in a busier environment but love ing to their village school, said Mr Page. He said: “Its easy to think to think that children in a small school may lack confidence because they’re not in a big environment.

title: china interpol chief investigated bribery
story: NewsInterpol chief Meng Hongwei is being investigated for bribery and other unspecied crimes say ChinaMeng Hongwei has not been seen since September  as he left Lyon in France, where Interpol is based, to travel to China.ShareCommentsByElaine McCahill:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsMeng Hongwei has not been seen since September  "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChina has said former Interpol chief Meng Hongwei is being investigated for bribery and other unspecied crimes. The news was announced via a statement on the Ministry of Public Securitys website on Monday.On Sunday, Interpol, the France-based global police coordination body, said that Meng had resigned as its president. Earlier on Sunday, China said it was investigating Meng, who is also a vice minister for public security in China, for suspected violations of the law. The investigation against Meng Hongweis taking and giving bribes and suspected violations of law is very timely, absolutely correct and rather wise, the ministry said in a statement following an internal meeting.  Meng has not been seen since September  as he left Lyon in France, where Interpol is based, to travel to China. Yesterday, Mengs we revealed he sent her a photo of kne before he disappeared. His we Grace believes the photo Meng sent her four days before he vanished was his way of saying he was in danger, US media is reporting. Grace, who is currently under police protection after receiving death threats, told reporters that four minutes after receiving the kne photo, Meng sent another message saying Wait for my call. She has not heard from him since.  Chinese authorities said yesterday he was under investigation for unspecied violations of the law. It comes as one source said the initial working assumption was that Meng had antagonised Chinese authorities in some way and had been detained as a result. France is puzzled about the situation of Interpols president and concerned about the threats made to his we, the ministry said, adding that it was in contact with China. It was not clear why Meng, , who was named Interpols president two years ago, had travelled to China, which has not commented officially on his disappearance. There have been several cases in recent years of senior Chinese officials vanishing without explanation, only for the government to announce weeks or even months later that they have been put under investigation, often for suspected corruption.  Hong Kongs South China Morning Post quoted an unnamed source as saying Meng had been taken for questioning as soon as he landed in China, but it was not clear why. French police are investigating what is officially termed in France a worrying disappearance. Hours later, Interpol said in an official statement that Hongwei had resigned from his position with immediate effect. Kim Jong Yang of South Korea has replaced him as acting president. until a new president can be elected at the next General Assembly Session in Dubai, November -.  Interpol, which groups  countries and which is usually focused on finding people who are missing or wanted, said in a statement from its secretary general, Juergen Stock, that it had asked China for clarication. Interpol has requested through official law enforcement channels clarication from Chinas authorities on the status of Interpol President Meng Hongwei, Stock, who is in charge Interpols day-to-day running, said on Saturday. Roderic Broadhurst, a professor of criminology at Australian National University, said Mengs disappearance would be pretty disconcerting for people in international bodies that work with China. It added that it could ultimately damage Chinas efforts to develop cooperative legal assistance measures with other countries.  It is bizarre, Broadhurst said on Saturday, adding that China was likely to brush off any political damage that it would cause to Beijings involvement in international bodies. Its a price that might have to be paid, but I guess they would see that as a cost worth bearing, Broadhurst said. Presidents of Interpol are seconded from their national administrations and remain in their home post while representing the international policing body. Meng is listed on the website of Chinas Ministry of Public Security as a vice-minister, but lost his seat on its Communist Party Committee in April, the South China Morning Post reported. Meng has almost  years experience in criminal justice and policing, and has overseen matters related to legal institutions, narcotics control and counter-terrorism, according to Interpols website.

The -year-old, named by police as Burak S., was seen filming himself on his phone after he opened up a customers pizza outside of their home and leaned over it smiling. Prosecutors believe the teenager was filming himself spitting on the pizza before delivering it. Burak S. is then said to have walked up to customer Huseyin Alyuzs fth-floor flat, in the city of Eskisehir in north-western Turkey, to deliver the meal. However, Mr Alyuzs nephew, Cagatay Ehe, saw the CCTV footage and quickly told his uncle, who then complained to the police and the pizza company.  Burak S. denies spitting on the pizza but has been sacked from his job and now faces serious charges which could see him jailed for an incredible  years. He has gone on trial in a criminal court charged with endangering the lives of persons by putting poison or spoiling the food with other means which carries a sentence of two to  years in prison. And he also faces a consumer court charge of damaging goods and endangering customers health which carries a sentence of between four months and three years behind bars. Burak S. told the criminal court that he did not spit on the pizza and had only opened the box to ensure it was not damaged as he had been in an accident enroute. He said: I found out that the person who ordered the pizza had cursed my colleague Aylin. I knew he was a problem customer. I opened the box of the pizza to check for any problems, to check whether the pizza was still intact. I took a picture of the pizza with my mobile phone and sent it to my friend Aylin. I absolutely did not spit when I opened the box. However, Mr Alyuz told the court: I called the pizza shop and ordered a pizza. It was a two-minute conversation and I did not curse anybody.

title: blether josie one of four dundee boxers to step in ring with benny lynch
story: Lochee ex-Pat Rob Boag came up with some interesting stuff while having a clearout.He revealed: “Sting through old photos, I came across a snap taken in  of my uncle Joe Boag, who, at that time, was aged .“With the photo was a copy of his  boxing licence.“Known in his birthplace of Lochee as ‘Josie’, the address on the licence was A Atholl Street. When you leaned over the bunker in A Atholl Street, the living room window had a fine view of Maloney’s park.“A boxing licence wasn’t a bad thing to have in Tipperary!“Josie was known as Mr Lochee, and he knew every character and every family in Tipperary – and beyond. He was a gted story teller and selecting words the way an artist selects colours from a palette, Josie painted you a story.”Rob continued: “When he described training as a young lad in the Camperdown Boxing Club under the watchful eye of the old pro Johnny Dougan, you were there with him.“There was humour and pathos in his stories of how families survived the hard times of the  s – and they were hard.“Josie’s tales of the devious antics used to poach players from one football team to another was always entertaining.“Anyone who stopped to have a blether with Josie Boag left with a smile on their face.”Joe once came up against a world-class boxer, as Rob went on: “He was one of four Dundee boxers – Freddie Tennant, Jim Brady and Willie Vogan the others – to climb through the ropes and have a go with Benny Lynch.“The decision in Glasgow was a draw between Joe and Benny.“Joe’s purse was £, with travel expenses coming out of that richly sum.“The trophies held by Joe in the photo were gts from Danny O’Sullivan, a British bantamweight champion in the late s.“In , when World War  started, Joe enlisted with the RAF regiment and, after basic training, was transferred to Montrose air base as a physical trainer and boxing instructor.“One evening in , a new posting – a young lad from London came into the gym and askedhe could work out.“His name was Danny O’Sullivan, and Joe was amazed to see what Danny did to the punch bag. Joe coached the young Londoner and entered Danny into every amateur boxing contest in Scotland at that time, and was in his corner for every fight.“Danny won the Scottish featherweight title – that is the medal Joe is holding in the photograph, and the cup was a winner’s trophy from another amateur boxing contest.”Rob revealed Joe introduced Danny to the Boag family and a lasting friendship began, and continued: “Back home in London after the war, Danny turned professional and, in , he won the British bantamweight title. He also fought for the European and world titles.“When stationed in England in  during my National Service, any -hour pass coming my way was spent in London with the O’Sullivans.“Danny’s brothers, Dick and Mickey, both ex-professional fighters, took me under their wing and it was a weekend blur of snooker halls, boxing gyms, pubs and introductions to a host of cockney characters.“Mickey O’Sullivan’s grandson is Ronnie O’Sullivan, the legendary world snooker champion.“The coach and the champ maintained contact with each other until Joe died in .“Danny kept involved with his sport, and was active in events that supported amateur boxing.“Danny passed away in .”

title: can roarie be dundees deacon of hope
story: Former Arsenal kid Roarie Deacon’scoincided with Dundee’s first league victory of the season – could he be the piece that’s been missing from their Premiership jigsaw The -year-old, who signed from English National League side Sutton United last summer, has missed the entire start of the season after having ankle surgery.Picking up the injury in the final game of last season, the enigmatic attacker ed for the final six minutes of the club’s first league win of the season – at the seventh time of the asking – at Hamilton and, in the process, set up the second goal.And hiswas hailed by manager Neil McCann.He said: “Roarie Deacon I am really pleased about getting back in because we have suffered some real injury problems of late.“He hadn’t featured at all, he’d only had  minutes of football all season before Saturday but I knew putting him on he could secure the ball because he is so strong.“You can’t get close to Roarie and he turned the boy beautully, then he had the composure.“I have to commend the other boys as well because they were still trying to get into the box at that stage to get the killer goal.”Deacon himself was delighted to be back in action after his y spell out.A process that was extended after an older injury reared its head once more.His debut season was also curtailed by injury with a troublesome thigh problem picked up in December at Hearts keeping him out of action for a big chunk of the middle of the campaign.And, on histo training this season, he hurt the same thigh once more.Deacon said: “I had ankle surgery the first week into pre-season.“I twisted it and damaged ankle ligaments in the game against Partick and through the summer it didn’t heal itself.“The surgeon didn’t want to operate initially but it didn’t heal itself so we made the decision to go under the kne to sort it out.“I was supposed to be back a little earlier than this but on the first session back I re-injured my thigh, a problem I had last season, so I needed a bit of intense rehabilitation on that to get back.“Now, though, I am ready to go and I’m fit.”With goals being a real issue for the side – just four scored in their seven league games and half of them against Accies at the weekend – Deacon’sis a timely boost for the Dark Blues.In fact, he’s only played around six minutes this season but has already had a hand in a quarter of their league goals.Coming into the side struggling for goals and points, though, hasn’t ruffled Deacon in any way.And Dundee fans will be hoping his direct running and ability to go past people is the key that unlocks defences with tough matches against Kilmarnock on Saturday and then Livingston, Hearts and Celtic in the next month.The former Sutton man admits he’s surprised the Dark Blues find themselves bottom of the table as he s to fitness and has backed them to get up the table,they keep doing what they’ve been doing.He added: “I am very surprised, everyone is surprised.“No way we thought we would come in, do well in pre-season, and then come in and after six games not have a point on the board.“However, after Hamilton everyone is positive, you can’t not be because the way we’ve been playing it’s not like we’ve not created chances or played well despite not getting points.“Everyone is buzzing about in training, raring to go and wanting to do well for Dundee.”

title: dundee basketball team makes dream come true for young baller molly 8
story: A Dundee basketball club has made a dream come true for a young disabled Irish girl.Eight-year-old Molly McNamara, from Achill Island off County Mayo on the west coast of the Republic of Ireland, has cerebral palsy.Her lelong dream has been to play basketball, which she adores.Now, thanks to Dundee Madsons and one of their coaches, Steph Robertson, Molly has been able to achieve her dream.She also joined the club’s under– team when they acted as mascots for Caledonia Pride Women’s team at a big game in Edinburgh last weekend.Debbie MacCallum, of the club, explained that Steph runs her own personal training business and that was how she first met Molly.She said: “When Steph began working with Molly in , she couldn’t stand up.“Steph visits Ireland six times a year and Molly trains every day following a programme she has developed for her.“At the last count Molly took over  steps independently and can walk with sticks, and run with her walker.“She happened to be in Scotland for a course the weekend when the Dundee Madsons Under– Girls basketball team were playing in the Regional Development League in Ellon.“Molly had been asking Steph for years about the basketball and that weekend she joined in the training and she loved it – and the girls loved her.“She was invited up to the games with the intention that they would ask the other team coachesshe could take throw–ins but,this wasn’t possible, she could join the team on the bench and join in the warm-up. The other team’s coaches were fantastic.“In the first two games she took the throw–ins a few times then, in the third, she took part in the game.“She is now % a ‘Madson’ and has joined the family. She will always train with them when she is over in Scotland.”Molly’s mum Natasha said: “Steph and the Dundee Madsons have been truly amazing.“This opportunity means so much to Molly, especially acting as a mascot leading out Caledonia Pride.”

title: local councils owed thousands for school meals as parents at dundee school revealed as most in debt
story: Parents and carers across Tayside are falling into tens of thousands of pounds of debt because they haven’t paid for their kids’ meals or snacks in nurseries and schools.A Tele investigation has revealed local authorities in Dundee, Angus and Perth and Kinross are owed signicant sums of money.And at least two of the councils have written off thousands of pounds owed to them by mums and dads after failing to get the money back – even after taking legal action in some cases. vw, px"  More than , families in Dundee owed a collective £,. to the council by the end of August.In Angus, as of just two weeks ago, parents owed £,.A further £, was owed by parents in Perth and Kinross at the end of   – the most recent date available.Although there’s no suggestion that children are being refused food as a result of their parents’ debts, experts say the figures show the pressure family budgets are under.John Dickie, director of the Child Poverty Action Group in Scotland, said: “It is vital that all of Dundee’s children have access to healthy snacks and lunches whatever their family circumstances, and charging and payment collection policies need to recognise the extraordinary financial pressures so many families are under.“Our Cost of the School day project in Dundee schools found that the online Parent Pay system reduces the risk of pupils losing or forgetting lunch money, but several schools report that it has led to some families falling into lunch debt.“This means following up with families for late payments, with risk to home-school relations.”Parents at Forthill Primary School in Broughty Ferry owe the highest amount of money to the council, at £,., while the most owed to a nursery is £. at Jessie Porter in Downfield.In the last five years, Dundee City Council has written off £, owed for snacks or meals, which cost between p and £. per day.A spokesman said: “The council has a school meal debt protocol which has been operating in schools for almost a year.“This recommends, among other things, that head teachers and administration staff should meet fortnightly to discuss lunch debt.“Given that the schools know the pupils and their families, they are best-placed to determinethey need signposted to organisations who may be able to support themthey are struggling.”Tracy McNally, director at Dundee Citizens Advice Bureau, says the service has helped  families with debt this year.She said: “Households are worrying about the ability to afford food, the limited choice and feeding their family healthy food on a limited budget. vw, px"  “This then leads to people borrowing money, using credit, receiving foodbank vouchers as a way of obtaining food or, in many cases, limiting food intake.”Since  , Perth and Kinross Council has written off more than £, owed by parents.A spokesman said: “An invoice and reminders will be sent to parents or carers. If the money owed is not subsequently paid, the debt will then be passed to sherf officers to seek collection.”Angus Council sends letters and texts to parentsthey fall into debt of £. or more.A spokesman said: “Where parents or carers highlight any dficulties they are experiencing to us, we will always work with them to ensure that a solution is found to ensure no child goes without a lunchtime meal.”Margaret Williams, , East EndIt’s shockingthe schoolhas the highest level of unpaid meals because I’m sure the parents can afford it. Means-testing would help because there are a lot of people at this school who can afford to pay for their children’s meals.Lesley Scott, , Broughty FerryIf parents can’t afford to pay for the meals, maybe that is something that needs to be looked at. If people are just chancing it by not paying, then that is out of order. Many years ago, with my older children, I struggled to pay for school meals.Tim Twine, , Broughty FerryThe schoolcovers a large intake area – there are affluent people and less affluent people. It may not have anything to do with it, but it could be a factor. If people can’t afford school meals, they should make a packed lunch.Margaret McAndrew, , FintryI think the schools should maybe send letters out to the parents and let them know, because it’s not fairsome people are paying and some aren’t. Parents should pay for the school mealsthey are supposed to.

story: Monikie farmer Fleur Baxter is hoping her latest artwork can raise £, for Macmillan Cancer Support.Fleur’s wacky straw bale creations have previously included a Pokemon-themed display and a Minions-inspired work.She got the spray paint out again to create Dennis the Menace, Gnasher, Desperate Dan and a cow pie to brighten up the landscape near Monikie Primary School.Fleur, of East Skichen Farm, said she has set up a JustGiving page for fundraising connected to the creations.“I’ve never asked for donations before but this year is dferent,” she said.“This summer my father was diagnosed with aggressive and incurable laryngeal cancer and this year there needs to be a little more purpose to my wild graffiti antics than ever.”People can donate to the cause at justgiving fundraising fleur-baxter.

title: neil mccann backs his dundee players to handle the heat
story: Dundee will have to face a dferent kind of pressure this weekend against Kilmarnock but manager Neil McCann is backing his players to handle it once again.The Dark Blues boss was full of praise for the way his defence dealt with Hamilton’s direct approach in the second half of their - victory.Accies brought on strikers Rakish Bingham and on-loan Mason Bloomfield as they bombarded the Dundee defensive line.However, with the help of the crossbar a couple of times, Dundee held out and lted some of the heat that’s been on the manager and his team after the six straight defeats that began their season.With Killie’s attacking line of Greg Stewart, Eamonn Brophy, Jordan Jones, Chris Burke and Kris Boyd it’ll be a dferent sort of pressure the Dark Blues will have to be ready to deal with.Neil, though, expects the edginess in their defending as they homed in on their first win to be gone come Saturday.He said: “The next game will be a tough one against Kilmarnock but we enjoyed last weekend because it had been a long time coming.“Against Hamilton, I knew they would go direct, they brought Bingham on and did go more direct.“You have to deal with that – there is only so much you can do as a manager, tactically, and the players have to deal with it.“You have to be able to deal with the threat of them going direct.“There was a wee bit of edge still in their game because I’ve been saying for weeks I’d love to see them go in front and see what it did to their game.“I always knew they would still be playing with pressure but they dealt with that.“They had to deal with long balls, there were a couple of balls flashed across the goal but I thought we were well worth our three points last Saturday.”Meanwhile, a Dundee reserve side including first-teamers Jack Hamilton, Darren O’Dea, Jesse Curran and Jean Mendy were thrashed - by Dunfermline at Kelty Hearts’ New Central Park.It was Jimmy Boyle’s men’s first defeat in the Reserve League with goals from Lewis McCann, two from former Dundee United man Robbie Muirhead and second-half penalties from Tom Beadling and Myles Hippolyte counting for the Pars.The match did see a first outing for new Dee signing Grant Nelson.The -year-old from Rangers signed up with Boyle’s reserve side before the contest.

title: new bbc series to put dundee area firmly on the map
story: A Dundee community group hopes a new BBC Scotland documentary series will “put Lochee on the map” as it explores social issues in the city.The six–part series will follow members of the Save Our High Street group, alongside other communities in Scotland that have been hit by poverty.Treasurer of Lochee Community Partnership Myles McCallum said: “Some residents in Lochee might be deprived financially but they’re not deprived of community spirit.“We want to show the real people of Lochee. The area has a rich history and there’s a lot that could be done with the High Street.”BBC Scotland has confirmed it will be filming in Dundee and the series will be presented by award-winning author, rapper and social commentator Darren McGarvey.Mr McGarvey, also known as Loki, wrote Poverty Safari – a novel discussing issues faced by deprived communities all across the UK.The Save Our High Street group has already taken the BBC on a tour around Lochee.Last Tram bar manager Karen Beattie is being hailed by the group as the “star” of the programme.She said: “The poverty in the area is getting worse – you can see people on the street begging and families that are struggling.“We are hoping the series will be a good thing for Lochee.“I was quite shocked that we got picked.”Group co-chairwoman Jayne Kelly said the programme will discuss the city as a whole – as well as its substance abuse problem.She said: “It’s great news – we’re dead chuffed because it’s another positive for the community.“We made it really clear we want it to be a positive programme.”Mr McCallum said: “I want to see wee independent shops on Lochee High Street – similar to those on Perth Road.”The documentary is expected to air in early .

title: revealed plans for 60m housing leisure commercial and hotel development at dundees waterfront
story: Plans for a £ million housing, leisure, commercial and hotel development at Dundee’s Waterfront have been revealed.Glasgow-based Dawn Developments has lodged an intention to submit a full planning application with Dundee City Council.The firm has notied the council that it will be seeking to apply for permission for a mixed development including offices, hotels, housing and commercial units at site  at the Waterfront.One of the company directors, Paul O’Donnell, told the Tele that this was to be a “signicant and major” development.He said: “These are the very early stages, and we are about to enter into consultations regarding our proposals.“However, it would be accurate to say at this stage that this will be a signicant and major development at the Waterfrontit gets the go-ahead.“We are now at the stage of entering into full consultations and negotiations to take this forward.“If this all goes according to plan we would hope to submit a formal planning application to the council during the first quarter of .“If our application is approved work will progress as expected after that.”Mr O’Donnell said that the full details of their proposals had still to be finalised.However, he added they were hoping to develop housing, offices and hospitality at the site.He said: “We are proposing  mixed–size residential properties of mixed tenures, and hospitality units such as a hotels, restaurants and bars, but that has still to be finalised.“Over the coming months we will be holding consultations and talks in Dundee with ious interested parties.“These will obviously include city planners and developers, but it will also involve members of the public.”He said that several public consultations would be held but no dates had been set for these yet.“We have an obligation to hold public consultations and these will take place. I think more than one of these will be held. We will be putting out further information regarding this in due course,” he said. Mr O’Donnell added that the company had selected Dundee for the development because they considered it to be the place to invest.“There is a lot going on in Dundee and we are keen to be involved,” he added.“It’s not just because of the VA but also everything  that is going on in the city at the moment.“We’ve decided we want to invest in the city and be a part of its future.”A spokesman for the city council confirmed they had received the planning application notice and said that this was the very early stages of the proposals.Meanwhile, work is progressing on site  at the Waterfront.It, too, will include restaurants, cafes, bars, offices and housing.It is hoped that work will be complete by next summer.

title: Fee introduction was a factor in recyling rate dip but just a blip insists Highland Council
story: THE controversial introduction of the fee for emptying brown bins was a factor in the arearsquos dip in recycling rates last year.But Highland Council chiefs say it was just a blip.While the level of household waste recycled nationally exceeded the amount sent to landfill for the first time, the tonnage slipped in Highland.The regionrsquos  recycling feat of . per cent dropped last year to . per cent ndash and last year a pound charge was brought in for emptying garden waste bins. This fee was increased to pound this year.The councilrsquos vice convener Allan Henderson, who also is also chairman of the environment committee, said: ldquoWhile wersquore getting better at recycling, the change to charging for brown bins has meant some garden waste being channelled into municipal waste.ldquoI believe our proposal to build a lsquomaterial recovery facilityrsquo and roll out extra brown bin coverage will reverse this slight dip.The latest figures from the Scottish Environment Protection Agencyshow that recycling rates improved at  of Scotlandrsquos  local authorities.It estimates that . per cent of waste generated in Scotland was recycled, which was an annual increase of . per cent.Scotlandrsquos environment secretary Roseanna Cunningham welcomed the figures but said more progress was needed, particularly in the cities.The biggest increases in recycling rates were in West Lothian, East Renfrewshire, Dumfries and Galloway, South Ayrshire and Aberdeen City.Ms Cunningham said: ldquoThe Scottish Government has big plans for tackling waste plastics, in particular by introducing a depositscheme, to further incentivise people to recycle.ldquoWersquove also introduced a household recycling charter for local authorities to sign up to, which is making the approach to recycling less confusing for households and creating a more consistent and efficient system for authorities.The Sepa figures show the amount of household waste generated in Scotland was . million tonnes in  ndash a decrease of , tonnes from .Monday  Oct  : PM

title: Gaelic centre plan has backing of Inverness public
story: A SURVEY has shown that there is signicant public support for a new Gaelic cultural centre in Inverness.The research, which was carried out by the Alba Heritage Trust with the aim of establishing the level of interest in a project celebrating Gaelic heritage, was met with ldquooverwhelming backing from members of the public.Alba Heritage Trust director Alastair Forbes says the reaction has from businesses and iniduals across the board has been signicant.ldquoWe are delighted to have had so many responses to the survey, he said.ldquoThe reaction from the public and private sectors and from members of the community for the establishment of a Gaelic cultural centre has been extremely positive which has given us great confidence in moving forward with the project.Dr Blackrsquos Memorial Hall in the city centre has already been earmarked as a potential venue for the initiative ndash backed by an architectural survey.Plans for potential facilities in the centre include a Gaelic cafeacute, a retail space selling Gaelic-themed products, and language classes as well as a cultural exhibition.It would also host ceilidhs, shows and performances, as well as talks and lectures on the subject of Gaelic culture.Alba Heritage Trust director Emily Macdonald said: ldquoA cultural centre of this type would be of great benefit to the city of Inverness and the wider Highland area.ldquoIt would provide a focal point for anyone with an interest in Gaelic language and culture.ldquoThe potential impacts include promoting Gaelic language and culture, increasing Gaelic usage, encouraging community interaction, attracting further cultural events to the city, creating jobs and enhancing Invernessrsquos offering as a centre for tourism.Monday  Oct  : PM

title: Port cruises to best ever year
story: THE Port of Cromarty Firth recorded its best ever year in , with almost pound million in turnover, it has reported.Its annual review reports a turnover of pound. million ndash pound million higher than its previous turnover record in .A ersication from its core business of oil and gas to renewables, decommissioning and cruise and a higher number of vessels than expected resulted in the improvement. Many of the visitors have been taken by coach to hot spots such as Inverness and Loch Ness.The strong results will allow the port at Invergordon to continue to invest in major developments, such as the new quayside and laydown space, which is in the planning stages for construction through Chief executive Bob Buskie said: ldquoAt the start of , with low oil and gas prices, we knew the port had to adapt to sustain our growth and help keep local people in work.ldquoFirstly, supporting our core customers in oil and gas was a key concern.ldquoAfter the necessary consultation, we introduced a new pricing for statutory dues in January , which meant an average five per cent reduction in fees for most clients, supporting them through the downturn.ldquoSecondly, the port had to look to the future and see what we could do to help sustain jobs and growth.The cruise-liner market was a success last year, with the port being named as the busiest in Scotland. It welcomed  ships and more than , passengers mdash a  per cent increase on . The direct spend from passengers is put at pound million.The port has outlined plans to build a new multi-use berth development to provide modern facilities and to accommodate the larger cruise ships.The port also ran two workshops, in conjunction with the cruise companies and Highlands and Islands Enterprise, to help local businesses understand and work with this lucrative sector. A cruise stakeholder group was also established to help improve logistics and communication.Port board chairman Douglas Russell said hard work by its staff saw produced the record-breaking year.Monday  Oct  : PM

title: Pressure on Highland Council to stub out unethical investments
story: HIGHLAND Council could review its stake-holding in tobacco, alcohol and weapons companies.Opposition to such selections was spelled out by Ross-shire councillor Angela MacLean amid long running anger about the ethics of the local authority investing millions of pounds in such industries while also claiming to promote ldquohealthy lestyles through council policies.Over the past  years, a small band of councillors has registered opposition to widely perceived ldquounethical investments but to no effect.Independent fund managers are employed to get the maximum . Recent figures showed the fund increased in value in - by pound. million. As of last weekend, it was valued at pound,,,..Addressing colleagues on the audit and scrutiny committee, Cllr MacLean called for a review of investment strategy. She acknowledged the need to secure the best .But she added: ldquoSome people are not happy with some of the investments and feel that perhapsitrsquos invested in tobacco or arms or things like that, itrsquos not ethically responsible.She asked whether fund trustees had any say in the choice of investments.The councilrsquos investments change on a daily basis.Recent examples of contentious choices include British American Tobacco , liqueurs firm Pernod Ricard , pubs chain Mitchells and Butlers , Japan Tobaccoand Chinarsquos second largest brewery, Tsingtao .The councilrsquos finance director Derek Yule explained that an investments sub-committee reports to a pension board which sets the strategy.ldquoIt is very dficult when some of the investment strategy seeks to invest in shares in companies not just in the UK but worldwide, he said.ldquoWhilst I totally understand some of the ethical debate, it is very dficult to draw a line sometimes.ldquoYou might take a viewhellip would you invest in banks, for example  They might not be the best investment, anyway. But I use that as an example because banks will fund these companies.ldquoItrsquos a dficult balancing act but itrsquos certainly within your rightsyou wished the pension board to look at the investment strategy.ldquoFund managers are given guidelines to work to, so that would be quite legitimate for the council to do through the pension board.According to current policy, the fund ldquorecognises that social, environmental and ethical considerations are among factors investment managers will take into account, where relevant, when selecting investments for purchase, retention or sale.However, it stresses that ldquothe overriding consideration for pension committee members is their fiduciary duty to the scheme employers and scheme members.The Scheme Advisory Board, established up by the Scottish Government to regulate such public sector pension funds, recently obtained advice from legal counsel on the duty of pensions committees.The guidance concluded that: ldquoPensions committees in Scotland owe a fiduciary duty to the scheme employers and the scheme members in general and specically in relation to investment matters.ldquoThose duties should be exercised in the best interests of the beneficiaries and in relation to investment decisions, should aim to achieve the best financial position for the fund, balancing risk andin the usual way.Monday  Oct  : PM
