title: tributes-paid-to-great-guy-george-edgar
story: George Edgar, , passed away on September  and was buried on September  at Deer Park Cemetery, Dunbar.He had been a determined fundraiser for Macmillan Cancer Support, raising more than pound, since he was diagnosed with bowel cancer in .His we, Carol, led the tributes and said: ldquoHe was a loveable rogue. Honestly, he was just so happy and happy-go-lucky.ldquoHe never once let anything get him down. He was always a joker and a character.The keen sports fan was diagnosed with bowel cancer before Christmas six years ago.George, of Dunbarrsquos Rotary Court, underwent an operation to remove part of his colon and also endured gruelling chemotherapy.Unfortunately, he was later told the cancer was incurable.Despite that, George raised thousands of pounds for charity through golf, darts and football events.And his love of sport played a key part at his funeral, with those in attendance asked to wear bright colours or sporting tops.Carol, , said: ldquoHe loved golf, darts and football.George was previously involved with Dunbar Athletic Football Club and Callum White, who previously managed the side and is now the clubrsquos secretary, also paid tribute to a ldquodedicated man.He said: ldquoHe was one of those guys who was more behind the scenes and would help collect the strips, the money, and make sure everything was organised.Hannah Renton, owner of the Royal Mackintosh Hotel, where George had worked, described the dad and grandad as ldquoloved by all our staff.She said: ldquoHe was a great guy and a great head chef.ldquoHe took on the role when we opened up and only stopped because he had to stop working.ldquoHe was really hard working and would always go out of his way to do a lot.ldquoHe would still pop back in to see us.ldquoHe was a great guy and was loved by all our staff.Craig McLachlan, who owns Castle Park Golf Club near Gford, where Mr Edgar was a member, also offered kind words.A golf competition, the George Edgar Memorial Trophy, has been created.Mr McLachlan said: ldquoHe was hugely buoyant, hugely positive. He was a character who a lot of people could learn a lot from.ldquoHe raised a phenomenal amount for charity, even with working with us up here. I think in the short time we worked together for Macmillan we raised more than pound,.He will be sadly missed.And he added: ldquoI think it sums him up that earlier this year him and one of his good friends John Winters were going to be our charity representatives.ldquoWe were planning a charity weekend up here and sadly Georgersquos health overtook it.ldquoThat is an effort we will redouble next year, partly in his memory.

title: tranents-landmark-former-co-op-building-to-re-open-in-november
story: Mr Thomson, the townrsquos former postmaster, bought the former Co-op building in  with his we Susan, the current postmaster, and will install a cafe, bistro, childrenrsquos soft play, and Post Office into the building.He told the Courier: ldquoWersquore in the first phase, whichyou like is the Historic Scotland listed building part, which is going to be a brand new Post Office, convenience store, a coffee shop and bistro with about  seats inside and about  seats outside under a canopy. Thatrsquoll be opening in November.Mr Thomsonrsquos plans also include  flats for the building, which he hopes will be social housing.He said: ldquoWersquore hoping the whole thing can be finished by the start of May . The flats are going to be for social housing, preferably with East Lothian Council or East Lothian Housing Association, so really the timelines we have to do together.ldquoWe want social housing because therersquos a housing crisis in East Lothian and we want to try and help people with that.The Tranent resident was also very complimentary of the work of youth group Recharge.He said: ldquoRecharge have been in this building a very long time and Alan [Bell] runs it very well.ldquoOne of the key things that I wanted to make sure of when my we and I bought this building was we wanted to keep them on site as they do a fantastic job.After phase one is complete, work will start on phase two of the project.The next phase will include two small shops, flats, a soft play area and a community hall which will, it is hoped, hold about  people, as well as a kitchen and bar.Alan Bell, Recharge manager, was pleased the charity will get a new home within the building ndash they currently use part of the ground floor.He told the Courier: ldquoI think certainly, from our point of view, having a purpose-built facility will be fantastic.ldquoIt will really be able to extend the work we can do and help us reach out to a lot of young people that we currently struggle to engage with, because of our space limitations.ldquoWith it being purpose-built as well it means wersquoll be able to do more work with young people, so there will be rooms designed for specic tasks, whereas in here, we just adapt the rooms as we can. That will make a massive dference.He also reassured those who use their facilities at the moment that they will not be going away any time soon.Mr Bell added: ldquoThe building is secure and we will have a base to operate from whilst the work is being done. Recharge are still operating while the building is developed.

title: decision-soon-on-the-quay-plans
story: Amanda Chisholm, the independent reporter appointed to determine the appeal on behalf of Scottish Ministers, carried out an inspection of the site at Fisherrow Harbour last month.Lodged by Simply Musselburgh Care Limited, the appeal followed East Lothian Councilrsquos refusal of a plan to convert the former leisure complex, restaurant andsuites into a -bed nursing home.Ms Chisholm is now preparing her decision, a copy of which will be sent to all parties involved and published on the Planning and Environmental Appeals Divisionrsquos website.A meeting of the local authorityrsquos planning committee in June regarding The Quay, owned by Dr Charan Gill, ended with a near-unanimous decision to reject the nursing home proposal.Only Councillor Norman Hampshire, planning committee convener, backed council officialsrsquo recommendation to approve the plan.Local groups including Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council, Musselburgh Area Partnership, and Musselburgh Conservation Society, among others, are calling for the appeal to be thrown out., Musselburgh Area Partnership, Fisherrow Harbour and Seafront Association, and the Musselburgh Business Partnership are calling for the appeal to be thrown out.

title: tims-tales-johnny-moat-forever
story: The legend tells us that so long as the stone sits on the rocks, the town will flourish.It fell in  but was put back in  after a hard time for the town.It sadly fell again a few years ago, but at the time of the film Johnny Moat was sitting proudly on his ldquothrone on the Girdle Rocks.Film maker Marjory Boyle Crooks had been keen to capture the tale on camera. It was a lovely calm and sunny day, perfect for filming,I was halfway through the story when a group of local teenage lads approached. It seemed they were drinking and I anticipated them disrupting the filming.But I continued telling the story as it had been a perfect take up until that moment.The lads paused for a moment then all sat on the concrete walkway watching me and the film makers. They said nothing and seemed to be listening.I was able to complete my story uninterrupted.And as I walked away in the final shot I made eye contact with the lads and they respectfully waited until the filming had stopped before shouting, ldquoJohnny Moat forever! Then they got up and walked away.It was an unexpected and powerful moment for me.My assumptions about the lads had been utterly challenged as well.This was more than six years ago but I was reminded of it when I visited Johnny Moat this week with my wee boy Lewis.We were having our weekly storytelling walk in the Pans, a three-hour period between his nursery pick up and when I have to pick up his sister Skye from the Infant School.We just walk together visiting dferent places, and I tell him stories and he does the same.Most of his stories this day involved a T Rex or Raptor, which in his imagination wander about Prestonpans.So our respective tales were a bit dferent in content and style, but what is vital at this age is that he hears stories and is allowed to tell them freely.I told him the story of Johnny Moat and he said it looks like a whale.As we wandered from Johnny Moat up to Preston Tower, we stopped at what we call the lsquoStory Stonesrsquo.Here a small circle of stones sit underneath a cherry tree, with the tower looming behind. It is a perfect place to tell stories.Lewis gave me a new version of his T Rex tale here. I couldnrsquot understand all his story, but I got most of it.Then he said it was my turn so I told him a child-friendly version of the tale of the Green Lady. It made him want to go and look in the windows of the tower, which we did.The final story began at the old doorsquocot in the gardens by the tower. I explained it was a house for pigeons, but Lewis was having none of that.ldquoNo daddy, he said with a serious face, ldquoa lion lives there.ldquoReally  Can you tell me the story of the lion  I asked. And so he obliged.It was a great story, and we tracked the lion to the ancient Mercat Cross, where the unicorn sits on top of the pole ldquolooking for the lion.Then he spotted the lion on the  bus coming from Tranent.ldquoWill it eat the people  I asked.ldquoNo, he said asIrsquod asked an inappropriate question, ldquoitrsquos a nice lion.And so with the lion having left town, we headed for the Infant School to pick up his sister, but still keeping a look out for the T Rex.On the surface this may all seem a bit unusual, wandering about telling random stories that often didnrsquot make huge sense.But I value this time with my son, and as a storyteller I know the importance of it.Storytelling in this way when our kids are young helps develop what is called oral narrative ability, which gives a child the skills to explain and describe things, and develop their understanding of words and language.It fires their imagination and research shows that this can help with the enjoyment of reading and writing later on, and of telling and hearing stories.That night my son unexpectedly ed to the story of Johnny Moat.I had earlier told him it had fallen down and is lying face down in the sand and itrsquos too heavy to put back, but hopefully one day there will be a way.Like all kids his age, he took a while to process his thoughts on this. And these thoughts came out at bedtime.ldquoThe T Rex can put the big stone back, he said. I admired his total faith in the abilities of the T Rex.ldquoYes, maybe, I said. He fell asleep holding his T Rex which, for him, symbolises so much more than just an extinct dinosaur.As I headed downstairs, I thought about the connection between this day and the day over six years ago when I unexpectedly told the story of Johnny Moat to some teenage lads.Stories weave through us and bind us in a shared identity. But it made me sad that Johnny Moat still lies forgotten with his face in the sand.So Irsquom going to start looking for the T Rex of the Pans, whoever that may be, who can help. He or she must be out there somewhere. Or perhaps there is a crowd of them.The hope is that once my son is a teenage lad himself, he will be able to sit on the Girdle Rocks with Johnny Moat and tell the legend.

title: group-objects-to-750-new-homes-at-windygoul-south
story: A planning application for the site was submitted last month by Walker Group Ltd.The site plan extends Windygoul South to the Charles River Research Institute and Carlaverock Farm.But at a TECC meeting, members voiced their concerns over the proposals.Robert McNeill, community councillor, told the meeting: ldquoIn all my years on the community council, I canrsquot recall us making a formal objection about any developments in Tranent.ldquoWe try to be very proactive to any problems and find a solution. However, I think we really need to take a stand on this one.Mr McNeill added: ldquoI think we need to be clear that it will have a major impact on our community. Not just on schools, or traffic, but GPs and our health, the environment, the cemetery.ldquoI just feel thatwe donrsquot object to this application now, I donrsquot think I can continually voice my concerns about traffic and the impact on the community. I think itrsquos time for us to take a stand.ldquoBy objecting, we are making our views known, and itrsquos a view shared by many in Tranent.ldquoMaybe a lot of people donrsquot want to be vocal about it, but I do think itrsquos an opportunity that we cannot miss.ldquoI do think as a community we need to be sending a clear message out. Enough is enough. The community canrsquot take it any longer.David Forrest, TECC chairman, shared these concerns, pointing out the lack of infrastructure as the main reason for objecting to the plans.He said: ldquoGrounds for an objection has to be that the infrastructure in Tranent couldnrsquot cope with another  houses on the south side of Tranent.ldquoAll that traffic would be travelling through the centre, whether itrsquos to get to Edinburgh or just to go shopping.ldquoTranent is unique, traffic-wise, in East Lothian. You have Ormiston which has doubled or trebled in size, yoursquore going to have all these houses on the south side, and theyrsquore all still going to go down Tranent High Street. Nobody drives into North Berwick or Dunbar through the main street. Tranent is totally dferent.ldquoAnother  houses will all go through the main street in Tranent and thatrsquos the point wersquove got to get across.Fellow TECC member David Thomson added: ldquoEast Lothian Council made a statement about April, that there was no need to improve the infrastructure. However, on the recent Kingslaw planning application, they actually said that the impact on traffic from  houses would be excessive and detrimental to the local community.ldquoIf they deem that that  houses is excessive, how can they possibly say that  houses is not going to be three, four times, worse than that.ldquoUntil the roads are built they shouldnrsquot be building the houses.

title: teachers-time-in-turkey-inspires-her-debut-novel
story: Set in the Turkish capital Istanbul, Dr Margaret Halliday chose the location for her book as she worked as a teacher in the country for seven years.She decided to take up writing seriously five years ago when she was unable to live the same lestyle because of multiple sclerosis .An avid writer of diaries throughout her le, during which she saw the world, she planned to expand them into short stories when she retired.Dr Halliday, , who lives near Fisherrow, said: ldquoIrsquom excited about my first novel being published.ldquoAfter writing three memoirs, I wanted to try fiction as I had completed an Open University creative writing course.ldquoTaking the advice, lsquoyou should write about what you know,rsquo I chose Turkey for the setting as I worked there for seven years.The Belly Dancer is a tragicomic romantic thriller set mainly in Istanbul in the early s.Gemma, a young English woman, finds herself involved in more than just teaching English soon after her arrival in Turkey. Her love of belly dancing leads her into a relationship with the beautul Fatima as well as plunging her into a sinister, Mafia-run drugs operation.Dr Halliday said: ldquoI did not, however, belly dance or get involved with the Turkish Mafia and drug dealing ndash these had to be researched!ldquoLike Gemma, the heroine, I did teach English and visited Termal regularly, wallowing in the sparsquos waters just like her, as well as indulging in the occasional massage.ldquoNow I am putting together a collection of short stories, working title, Stranger than Fiction, about some of my weirder travel experiences. I have a character who Irsquod like to write another novel about but need to work on the plotrsquos development.Dr Halliday has published three autobiographical books ndash Prana Soup, an Indian Odyssey, which describes her travels around India Good Vibrations, which tells the story of a single s mum in Scotland and WWOOFing North and South, which relates her experience as a worldwide worker on organic farms in Scotland and New Zealand.Born in England in  with ldquogreen fingers and itchy feet, Dr Halliday undertook a yearrsquos training in Hastings Alexandra Park, followed by a horticultural course at the West of Scotland Agricultural College. She fell in love with Scotland, married a Scotsman and raised two children while working in scientic research and studying up to doctorate level.She qualied as a teacher of biology and chemistry and taught in ious schools and colleges in Edinburgh.Dr Halliday said her marriage broke up in , partly because of her ldquoitchy feet, and she went to live in Istanbul in , where she taught biological sciences at Marmara University for five years.After that, she taught English in Budapest and Damascus, exploring the countries and their environs in her holidays. Then she ed to Turkey and taught biology at a school for gted children near Istanbul.Her books are available via Amazon.as ebook and paperbacks.

title: housing-bid-at-edenhall
story: Stewart Milne Homes Central Scotland Limited is seeking East Lothian Council approval for the housing within the walled garden of historic Pinkieburn House, which was designed by renowned Scottish architect John Dick Peddie.The site, which was associated with the estate of the Lindsay family in the early th century, became disused in  following NHS Lothianrsquos decision to relocate services to the newly developed Musselburgh Primary Care Centre.The residential development would include  new homes for private sale, which range from four to six-bedroom detached homes.The th century buildings on the site would be ldquosympathetically restored to provide  new luxury apartments and homes.There would be a further  new affordable homes, providing one-bed apartments to three-bed terraced houses, ldquoensuring a wide mix of new homes for Musselburgh.A statement from the company added: ldquoThis will help address the critical need for new high-quality housing in the town ndash with careful planning and contextual design leading to the creation of communities that are designed to reflect the sitersquos local heritage.ldquoStewart Milne Homes intend to deliver a high-quality development, based around the unique heritage assets of the restored and converted listed buildings at Edenhall, including Pinkieburn House, the stables and gardenerrsquos cottage.ldquoCareful consideration has been given to the look and feel of this development to provide a sense of community and legacy.ldquoThe proposed residential development will involve conversion of the listed buildings to form flatted apartments, and extended cottage and other linked villas, along with new build houses for sale where within the site.ldquoThis will be an exciting opportunity to prevent the buildings and wider estate falling into further disrepair, and ultimately bring the setting back into appropriate residential use. Restoration and repair work will be conducted on a like for like basis, using materials to match the existing historic fabrics.It added: ldquoTo allow for high quality flood management, road access and opening the area for better daylight, some tree management work will be required.The site is allocated for residential development in the Proposed East Lothian Local Development Plan.The proposed housing development would be served by the existing access from Edenhall Road, with the existing junction widened through relocation of the gate piers.Gerry More, managing director of Stewart Milne Homes Central Scotland, said: ldquoFollowing our initial public consultation and exhibition two years ago, our proposals have been welcomed by the local community.ldquoOur vision is to create new communities that are fit for st century living, whilst incorporating traditional values and features.Speaking at a meeting of Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council last week, group chairwoman Irene Tait said the last time she was at the site it was ldquoall overgrown.She added: ldquoIt was horrible and dangerous, so it needs something done to it. They have got security measures but it becomes a danger for local children, although theyrsquore not supposed to be there.

title: update-rail-services-returning-to-normal-after-trespasser-on-the-line

title: schools-head-of-drama-sacked-following-disturbing-allegations
story: Daniel McLean-Steel, , was suspended by the headmaster of Loretto School in Musselburgh three weeks ago.Dr Graham Hawley contacted parents last week, the Courier has learnt, to inform them that Mr McLean-Steelrsquos employment had been ldquoterminated.Mr Hawley said: ldquoThe investigation has necessarily been a complex, detailed and thorough undertaking, and we have worked as expeditiously as we have been able.ldquoUnderstandably, during this period there have been a range of concerns and questions, and I hope that our personal responses to each have, wherever possible, served to inform and reassure you and others in so far as we have been able.ldquoThe investigation has now been completed, and the outcome of the process has been to terminate the employment of a member of staff, Mr Daniel McLean-Steel.The headmaster told parents he expected questions about the ldquonature of the complaint.But he said he was not revealing any details in his statement ldquofor legal reasons, despite also confirming that there was no active police investigation.In a previous statement, issued on September , the headmaster said that he had been ldquodeeply disturbed by these allegations" and took them "very seriously".Mr Hawley has now said: ldquoAs I have already indicated in my letter and statement of Wednesday  September , the allegations were in relation to behaviours which are unacceptable and have no place in our community, and the investigation has found this to be the case.ldquoI can confirm there is no active police case in association with this matter at this time, and I can also confirm the allegations presented did not relate to current pupils of the school."For legal reasons, it is not appropriate that I make further comment on this.The headmaster told parents he has begun a recruitment process to find a new head of drama. He also urged parents to contact himthey have any further concerns.When the allegations emerged Mr Hawley said he had alerted the Care Inspectorate.A spokesman for the Care Inspectorate said: ldquoWe are aware of an alleged incident at this school and are satisfied the school have responded appropriately.ldquoWe remain in close contact with the school. Anyone with a concern about a care service is encouraged to contact us.Mr McLean-Steel could not be reached for comment.

title: second-brexit-vote-does-not-set-precedent-for-scotland-first-minister
story: Scotlandrsquos First Minister has indicated her partyrsquos MPs would back a so-called Peoplersquos Vote on the United Kingdomrsquos exit from the European Union ,they were given the option.The SNP leader said that did not mean there would have to be a similar follow-up vote in the event of Scottish independence.Ms Sturgeon said the ldquodetailed proposition put to the public in the  independence referendum stood in stark contrast to the lack of detail available at the time of the  Brexit vote.Wersquore just getting startedhellip #SNP pic qcsDmNsWmdash The SNPOctober , On the issue of another vote on Brexit, the First Minister told BBC Radio Scotland: ldquoIf the vote presents itself in the House of Commons ndash I donrsquot know yet that it will ndash my view is that SNP MPs should vote for that.Asked whether that would then set a precedent for there to be a similar vote on any deal to leave the UK in the event of Scottish independence, Ms Sturgeon replied: ldquoIn my view, no, and Irsquoll explain exactly why.She told the Good Morning Scotland programme: ldquoIf you look back to , there was a detailed proposition put to people in that referendum, the White Paper, which not everybody agreed with, obviously.ldquoBut it was a detailed proposition, setting out the implications, setting out in advance some of the compromises that would be required ndash currency union, for example, continued regulatory harmony.ldquoSo people knew what they were voting for. They knew the shape of the deal that the Scottish Government would then have negotiatedthe vote had been for independence.ldquoThe contrast between that and the  Brexit vote could not be starker. There was the lie on the side of the bus and nothing more.ldquoThere was no detail then, there is no detail now and it looks increasingly likely that when the UK leaves the EU at the end of March next year, there will still be no detail about the future relationship, and that makes these two situations, in my view, very dferent.The SNP is currently having its annual conference in Glasgow.On #bbcgms @NicolaSturgeon confirms that @theSNP MPs support for a nd #EU referendum across the UK will be unconditional but we will make the case for Scotlandrsquos position to be protected in the event of us being outvoted again @peoplesvote_uk #Brexit #SNPmdash Joanna Cherry QC MPOctober , Speaking on the first day of the gathering, senior SNP MP Joanna Cherry said Scotland would not necessarily have to have a second independence referendum to leave the UK.Addressing a fringe event at the conference, Ms Cherry suggested the partyrsquos over-arching goal could be achieved through a ldquodemocratic event, such as a general election.The pro-UK camapign group Scotland in Union branded the comments ldquodangerous and ill judged.Asked whether she agreed with Ms Cherryrsquos view, Ms Sturgeon told the radio show: ldquoMy view is, as it has always been, that the people of Scotland will decide the question of independence in a referendum. Thatrsquos the party position, that remains the party position.But she continued: ldquoIn defence of Joanna, I think itrsquos a bit rich for the opposition to have a go at SNP members for speculating about how we might be able to express our views on independence in circumstances where, in a fundamentally anti-democratic fashion, we have got opposition parties suggesting that they would block the ability to choose in a referendum.Prime Minister Theresa Mayrsquos official spokesman said: ldquoWe have made our position on this repeatedly clear.ldquoScotland already had an independence referendum just four years ago and voted decisively to remain in the UK. This should be respected.ldquoAs the Prime Minister has said, now is not the time for a second independence referendum, now is the time for the United Kingdom to be pulling together to get the right deal for the United Kingdom and the right deal for Scotland in ournegotiations.

title: devonport-chosen-as-base-for-new-navy-frigates
story: The type  frigateswill all be based in Plymouth, ending speculation they would be split between there and Portsmouth.Gavin Williamson made the announcement on Monday on board HMS Montrose, where he said thepound. billion programme would secure the future of Devonport.He said in a speech: ldquoThe largest naval base in western Europe, Devonport is the leblood of Plymouth and is as synonymous with this city as it is with our famous Royal Navy.ldquoShips have set sail from Devonportrsquos dock to defend our great nation for hundreds of years, and I can reveal that the truly world-class type  frigates will follow in their wake.ldquoWe are living in increasingly dangerous times, with the threats intensying both on and beneath the water. Plymouth should be in no doubt that it will be right at the heart of Britainrsquos fight for a safer world by homing these formidable warships.The ,-tonne frigate is designed for anti-submarine warfare and will enter service by the mid-s.They have been ordered from the BAE Systems shipyards on the Clyde, with four already named as HMS Glasgow, HMS Cardf, HMS Belfast and HMS Birmingham.After the speech Williamson said the plans would give confidence to the public about the Governmentrsquos plans for Devonport, which employs , people and generates  per cent of Plymouthrsquos income.Mr Williamson said: ldquoThis is going to be a massive boost for the area. This is a multi-billion pound programme which is going to ensure the future of the base.ldquoWe need to make sure the Royal Navy is in the best position to be able to plan for their future.ldquoThese are world-leading frigates. The Royal Australian Navy are also investing in these same frigates because therersquos a real clear understanding about the world-leading technology.ldquoThis will play an important part in keeping Britain safe for the future, important in ensuring that we have the capabilities to deal with the increasing threat of Russia.Asked whether Russiarsquos threat had prompted recent announcements of investment to defence, Mr Williamson said: ldquoThere is a recognition that the threat from Russia is stepping up, and this is why the commitment to the Type  to Devonport is timely at this moment.
