Despite her mums desperate attempts to persuade her toto the family dairy farm, the chef du jour remained committed to her calling"Mum came over to try and take me home but I refused," recalled Clare, who is also the first and only woman to run the kitchen of a three-Michelin-star British establishment, Restaurant Gordon Ramsay."I was so headstrong and, coming from a country background, ignorant of the dangers of the world."It has already been quite a year for Clare, who catered for Prince Harry and Meghan Markles evening wedding reception, and was named the number one female chef by the Worlds  Best Restaurants.Furthermore, just last week, the -year-olds first solo restaurant, Core, in west Londons lavish Notting Hill, was awarded two prestigious Michelin stars at the first attempt, only  months after it opened.Following Ramsays assessment of her, the racehorse trainers daughter admitted that shes a "big fan" of the Iron Lady.Ms Smyth, who admits she gets up at .am and goes to bed at .am, told the Sunday Times News Review: "To do what I do for  hours every day youve got to be single-minded, very focused. It takes a lot of grit." During a career peppered with stints under Heston Blumenthal, the Roux brothers and Michael Caines, Clare was working at Ramsays flagship restaurant in Cha by the time she was .After a spell at Alain Ducasses Le Louis XV restaurant in Monaco, she was lured back by Ramsay to be his head chef in London, where she became the first female British chef to hold and retain three Michelin stars.Referring to Ramsay - who once said "women cant cook to save their lives" - in glowing terms, she added: "Gordon is definitely not sexist he has one of the toughest kitchens in the world, and there are so many girls in there."A self-confessed perfectionist, Clare acknowledges that she used to be notoriously "harsh" on her staff - and she once admitted that she sacked "one person a week".In  she was awarded an MBE and then two years later she tied the knot with financier Grant Heath. The couple live in Wandsworth, south-west London, and would like children, although she added: "Im not sure Im ready to stop just yet."Addressing her eaterys high prices - £, £ and £ a head, excluding service and drinks - Clare is defiant: "If I was a lawyer with my reputation, can you imagine what Id be charging per hour "

Ireland AwardsBusiness AwardsSports AwardsProperty AwardsPrint SupplementSearchGoHome# News# Northern IrelandRecord number of pupils to sit transfer test in Northern Ireland" title"Pressure: pupils sitting an exam " width"" ""  " title"Pressure: pupils sitting an exam " width"" ""  Pressure: pupils sitting an exam By Allan PrestonOctober   CommentsRecord number of pupils to sit transfer test in Northern IrelandBelfastAn exam body has reported a record demand for transfer tests in Northern Ireland this year.https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland record-number-of-pupils-to-sit-transfer-test-in-northern-ireland-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph incoming article.ece cdea AUTOCROP h _Scottish_exam_res.jpgEmailAn exam body has reported a record demand for transfer tests in Northern Ireland this year..pushThe Association of Quality Educationis one of two bodies in Northern Ireland who arrange post-primary exams for entry to grammar schools. Stephen Connolly, AQEs joint chief executive, said , registrations had been received this year which he called an "unprecedentedly high figure". Pictured: Orangemans drunk dancing at Shania Twain gig lands him in cell  NI primary school principal kept silent about childrens abuse fears for years The  member schools provide , places for primary seven pupils to sit the exam.The overspill of  has meant some parents received letters to say their children will sit the exam at South Eastern Regional Collegein Lisburn.The arrangements have caused anger with some parents, according to Stephen Elliott from the Parental Alliance for Choice in Education ."Imagineyoure a -year-old in the greater Lisburn area you get a letter from AQE to say youre assigned to Lisburn tech to take your tests," he said."Not your primary school or the grammar school you hope to attend."Parents are absolutely not requesting this. I was called by a mother and grandmother who were very upset about it."He continued: "When you then have something as vital as the AQE tests which cost schools nothing, AQE are arbitrarily deciding where youngsters, who are already anxious about the future, have to sit the exam."Mr Elliott said he believed part of the problem was dficulty in securing teaching staff to supervise exams held on Saturdays.Mr Connolly said he could well understand why some parents could have been "disconcerted" by the arrangements."It would be very dficult to cope with the numbers eventhe applications were evenly distributed across all schools," he said, "but, almost inevitably, the over-subscription is to be found in what I shall call rather loosely the greater Belfast area, in particular Lisburn."Mr Connolly said the high popularity of the Lisburn schools meant the available spaces for assessments filled up quickly."It follows that they are not able to take candidates whose registrations are submitted late in the registration period," he said."We always try to accommodate the parents choices, which are ranked in order of preference from one to four, but the later in the registration period a registration is submitted, the more dficult it becomes to do that."We try to make that clear on the registration form."We then look at member schools who still have spaces left and would make our best endeavours to place a child in the nearest available."Last year, overspill arrangements meant some children had to travel  miles away to sit the tests in a dferent school."We were faced with a small number of parents who did not feel able to accept a place in a school so far away, although the majority did so without protest," Mr Connolly said."The situation was resolved when, making extraordinary efforts, schools in the required proximity released some additional spaces."Mr Connolly said the arrangements for an overflow centre with SERC were made to minimise inconvenience in the Lisburn area.Mr Connolly concluded: "In other words, while our wish is always to place any child in the centre of his or her choice, the scale of the registration has prevented us from doing that."Our member schools do the very best they can, but their resources in rooms and staffing are not limitless and AQE has to achieve the best solution it can in those circumstances."

Ireland AwardsBusiness AwardsSports AwardsProperty AwardsPrint SupplementSearchGoHome# News# Northern IrelandSinn Fein challenging council sale of Raymond McCreeshThe Raymond McCreesh Park in Ballybot, NewryOctober   CommentsSinn Fein challenging council sale of Raymond McCreeshBelfastSinn Fein have announced they are going to challenge a council decision to sell off the controversial Raymond McCreesh Park in Newry. https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland sinn-fein-challenging-council-sale-of-raymond-mccreesh-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph news article.ece e AUTOCROP h --_new__I.JPGEmailSinn Fein have announced they are going to challenge a council decision to sell off the controversial Raymond McCreesh Park in Newry..pushIt was revealed last week that Newry, Mourne and Down District Council were planning to dispose of the Ballybot park, which has caused controversy after it was renamed in tribute to the former IRA man in . Council set to sell park named after IRA man Raymond McCreesh  McCreesh play park defended during republican rally Following a report into play park provision in the council area it had been decided to dispose of the park and replace it with a new park nearby.There are also plans to build  new houses in the area.However, Sinn Fein have announced they will challenge the decision through a call-in procedure.A call-in allows councillors to request that an issue be reexaminedthey feel that it was not handled correctly or will have an adverse impact on a particular section of the community. Newry Sinn Fein councillor Liz Kimmins said that her party wanted a community consultation on the issue.“The Council decision to dispose of Raymond McCreesh Park without community consultation is against with the wishes of local residents in the Barcroft and Ballybot areas," Councillor Kimmins said.“At last Monday’s meeting Sinn Fein opposed the disposal based on concerns raised by local residents and community groups and proposed a full community consultation. “This was rejected by the SDLP and unionist parties which is hardly surprising given that they have always wished to remove the name of Raymond McCreesh Park.Raymond McCreesh“Despite the fact that ten play parks in Newry  Mourne Council area have been declared as surplus assets, Raymond McCreesh is the only one that has been fast-tracked for disposal." Unionists and IRA victims had repeatedly called for the name of the park to be changed.The SDLP initially supported the renaming of the park, but have changed their stance in recent years.McCreesh, from Carnlough in Armagh, was reportedly in possession of a rle used in the  Kingsmill Massacre killings when he was captured later that year. people were killed in the attack.McCreesh was one of seven IRA prisoners who died in the  Maze Prison hunger strikes.The hero banner erected at the childrens play park. Picture: NewraypicsHis convictions included attempted murder, conspiracy to murder, possession of firearms with intent to endanger le and IRA membership.In April a banner was hung on a fence in the park declaring McCreesh "our hero".

Ireland AwardsBusiness AwardsSports AwardsProperty AwardsPrint SupplementSearchGoHome# News# Northern IrelandTyrone priest Fr Gerard McAleer steps aside while historical claim is investigatedAllegation: Fr Gerard McAleerBy Jonathan BellOctober   CommentsTyrone priest Fr Gerard McAleer steps aside while historical claim is investigatedBelfastA priest has voluntarily stepped aside from his position over a historical claim made against him.https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland tyrone-priest-fr-gerard-mcaleer-steps-aside-while-historical-claim-is-investigated-.htmlhttps:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland article.ece fef AUTOCROP h --_new__I.JPGEmailA priest has voluntarily stepped aside from his position over a historical claim made against him..pushThe move comes after concerns were brought to the Archdiocese of Armagh and which are understood to relate to Fr Gerard McAleer, and which have been reported to gardai.The church said it would not disclose the priests identity or the parish where he serves. No detail was given about the claim made, but it is understood it relates to a period before the Donaghmore, Tyrone, parish priest was ordained. Fr McAleer - a former principal of St Patricks Boys Academy, Dungannon - is a well-known figure in GAA.He and Mickey Harte guided Tyrone to unprecedented underage GAA success in the s.When Tyrone won its first All-Ireland Senior Football Championship Final in , Fr McAleer was assistant manager.Eamon Martin, Archbishop of Armagh, asked for prayers for all concerned, adding that the man accused was entitled to a presumption of innocence.In a statement the Archdiocese of Armagh said: "In line with the safeguarding policy and the standards and guidance of the National Board for Safeguarding Children in the Catholic Church in Ireland, a parish priest of the archdiocese of Armagh has voluntarily stood aside from his position because of concerns brought to the diocese and reported to the gardai. "The information received is historic and relates to a time prior to his time in ministry in the archdiocese, and indeed prior to his ordination as a priest. "The relevant statutory authorities in Northern Ireland have been informed."The Archbishop of Armagh has asked for prayers for all concerned while stressing that during the period of the investigation the priest, who has voluntarily stepped aside from all his pastoral duties, continues to be entitled to the natural right of every person to the presumption of innocence pending the completion of all relevant State and Church processes."The PSNI and Garda did not respond to requests for comment.

title: new exhibition nerve visual gallery ebrington shines spotlight civil rights era
story: An exhibition featuring a special collection of artefacts highlighting some of the most signicant events of the Civil Rights era will go on display for the first time this weekend at the Nerve Visual Gallery in Ebrington.The Speeches, Strikes and Struggles: Curating Conflict exhibition is led by the Tower Museum, and offers the chance for the public to view rarely before seen collections highlighting key moments of the Troubles dating from  to the present day. The Speeches, Strikes and Struggles project combines resources from three major collections held in the museum archives - the Bridget Bond collection, the Gerry Lynch collection and the newly acquired Peter Moloney Collection.The exhibition will be launched at .pm on Friday October th by the Mayor of Derry City and Strabane District Council, Councillor John Boyle. Those attending will also hear from Harry Bond, Bridget’s youngest son and Peter Moloney himself.Looking ahead to the event, Emma McGarrity, Learning and Engagement Officer at the Tower Museum said: “The Curating Conflict exhibition offers visitors a chance to view a unique combinations of artefacts, some of which have never been seen before.“Gallery  is a testament to the le of Bridget Bond. She is representative of the tireless work of civil rights activists on the ground, who worked without reward for the betterment of the lives of others.“The Peter Moloney gallery creates a visual experience of the dferences and similarities across Northern Ireland society. We hope visitors will be able to recognise the cultural threads that we share, rather than the dferences that have ided us.”The first gallery in the exhibition showcases the struggle for Civil Rights in Northern Ireland from its roots in the late s. This is presented through the le and work of Bridget Bond, a leading civil rights activist in Derry. Secretary of the Derry Housing Action Committee and a member of NICRA, Bridget campaigned tirelessly for housing for the people of Derry and for basic human and civil rights for everyone.The exhibition showcases unique images fromLarry Doherty, Trevor McBride, Eamon Melaugh, and Victor Patterson and never before seen footage of Duke Street, from Liam McCafferty, which combine to illustrate the desire for social change in . Original documents from Bridget Bond’s collection are supported by material from the Gerry Lynch and Peter Moloney collections. Presented alongside archive material from the Linen Hall’s NICRA collection and the National Museums Northern Ireland, these documents illustrate key dates and activities from  through to .The exhibition also offers visitors the first chance to view material from the Peter Moloney collection, which consists of , items charting the identity and culture of Northern Ireland during the Troubles. Murals, badges, posters, banners, T-shirts and ephemera combine in a striking visual interpretation that provides a unique insight into a ided society.Reflecting on his collection Peter Moloney commented: “Some of my collection may upset people but we can’t rewrite history. My only wish is that people see it and learn from it.”Hosted in the Nerve Visual Building in Ebrington, the new Speeches, Strikes and Struggles: Curating Conflict is the latest event in the Nerve Centre’s programme of exhibitions, Exploring ‘. The programme aims to ask questions and encourage discussion around the legacy of Northern Irelands  fty years on.The exhibition will be open to the public from Thursday October th until Friday rd December . Opening hours at the Nerve Visual Building are Tuesday – Saturday am – pm and Sundays pm – pm.The exhibition is funded by the Esmée Fairbairn Collections Fund and the Heritage Lottery Fund.googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refresh

title: young derry people join bishop donal mckeown pilgrimage knock
story: Derry students who have received the Pope John Paul II Award or are currently working towards it have taken part in a pilgrimage to Knock.The young people were joined by Bishop of Derry Donal McKeown for the event which took place last month.The Award was launched in Derry in  by the Papal Nuncio, Archbishop Lazarotto. title: £1bn City Deal initiative could help tourism drive
story: HIGHLY ambitious proposals aimed at shaping future tourist provision in Newcastle are among the key projects included in Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos bid for a share of poundbn investment package under the City Deal initiative.City Deals are packages of funding and decision making powers which allow councils to boost the economy through the development of large projects in their respective areas.They are designed to allow councils to take charge and responsibility of decisions that affect their area, do what they think is best to help businesses grow, create economic growth and decide how public money should be spent.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is one of five councils paired with Belfast City Council, universities and the private sector who have committed poundm to help deliver a raft of schemes, with the remainder of the cash coming from the Treasury and Northern Ireland Executive.It is anticipated that the city deal initiative has the potential to help the councils create , new jobs over a -year period.Enterprising proposals to signicantly enhance tourism attractions in Newcastle were unveiled last year aimed at drawing international visitors to world class attractions in the resort.They include a gondola ride into the heart of the mountains and a visitor centre at the site of the old quarry at Thomasrsquo Mountain.Other proposals include an Alpine coaster ride enabling people to hurtle down the side of the mountain on a single track in a buggy, an indoor activity centre in Donard Park, elevated tree top walk in Tollymore Forest Park and new visitor centre and bird hide at the Murlough Nature Reserve.Consultants appointed to look at developing the resortrsquos visitor infrastructure also suggested constructing a new bridge under the main Kilkeel Road at the Bloody Bridge on the outskirts of the resort.City Deals have been hugely successful in other parts of the UK and the local council is hoping its funding bid will help deliver a step change in the regionrsquos economic fortunes and help achieve future growth.The local council has been working with its partners in close collaboration with the Civil Service, Ministry for Housing, Communities and Local Government and the Treasury to agree the priority projects for the programme of investment.It is also hoped to roll out superfast digital connectivity to enable businesses across the region to connect to new markets and opportunities and keep visitors for longer by investing in additional world class, authentic visitor attractions. There are also proposals to build on Strangford Loughrsquos tourism potential.Newry, Mourne and Down Council chairman Mark Murnin said the local authority was delighted to have reached a key milestone in the development of the Belfast Region City Deal.ldquoWe have in place an investment proposal that focuses on key investment initiatives within our infrastructure, our tourism, our digital connectivity, the skills and education of our people and innovation and digital capability of our businesses, he said.ldquoAs we move through the next stage of negotiations, we will continue to work closely with our partners and stakeholders to ensure that the city deal we secure will deliver on our ambition of a step change in economic performance and more and better jobs for our people.Cllr Murnin said the city deal process had helped to establish what he described as a ldquogenuinely collaborative working relationship across the region and is spearheading a new way of working for councils, the broader public sector, education and business.The local authority and its partners anticipate that an announcement will be made in the forthcoming autumn budget statement, paving the way for them to work up the respective proposals further..prettyPhoto

title: Ash shortlisted for music prize
story: THE new album from Ash has been shortlisted for this yearrsquos Northern Ireland Music Prize.Islands was released by Downpatrickrsquos Tim Wheeler, Mark Hamilton and Rick McMurray in May.The event, which will take place on November  at the Ulster Hall, is now in its sixth year and includes theof three categories that formed part of the very first NI Music Awards back in .Over  industry and media cast their vote for the best album of the last  months. They were also invited to nominate for Best Live, Best Single and the Oh Yeah Contender Award for best emerging act. There will be a second round of voting for all but Best Single, which will go to public vote later this week.The NI Music Prize is coordinated by the Oh Yeah Music Centre and is supported by Belfast City Council, Arts Council of Northern Ireland, British Council, PRS , PPL , Help Musicianrsquos Northern Ireland, Invest Northern Ireland and Tourism Ireland.The winners of each category will be awarded a cash prize. Best Single, Best Live Act and Oh Yeah Contender will receive pound, and pound, will go to the winner of Best Album..prettyPhoto

title: Ballygalget GAC opens new health and wellbeing centre
story: RESIDENTS of the Ards Peninsula will be able to enhance their health and wellbeing thanks to the completion of Ballygalget GACrsquos state of the art health and wellbeing Centre which was officially opened last Friday.The pound, flagship facility, which already has attracted  members, includes a state-of-the-art gym mdash The Camaacuten Fitness Suite mdash with  hour access, changing areas, health and wellbeing room and a fitness area for spin and other classes.The project received grant funding from the Rural Basic Services Scheme of the Northern Ireland Rural Development Programme - which is funded by the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairsand the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development.It was administered by Ards and North Down Rural Partnership Local Action Group. Funding was also provided by Ards and North Down Borough Council.Welcoming the new facility, Mayor of Ards and North Down Borough Council Richard Smart said the council was ldquodelighted to have provided financial support towards the project.ldquoThis state-of-the-art facility will improve the quality of provision and sporting experiences for people living within the Borough mdash something which Ards and North Down Borough Council is wholeheartedly committed to, he remarked.Jerome Burns, from DAERA, lead funder of the Health and Wellbeing Centre, said: ldquoThe Leader programme, through which this project has been funded, enables local people to determine the needs of their own area and decide how best to address these and this project is an excellent example of how the programme is delivering on the ground. I have every confidence that Ballygalget GAC, with its extensive network of volunteers and dedicated committee members, will make this project a resounding success.Paddy Coulter, chairman of Ballygalget GAC said: ldquoAs a club we have been overwhelmed by the generosity of local people and businesses who have rallied behind the project supporting fundraising initiatives such as our Club Lotto and Buy a Brick campaign.ldquoWithout their support and that of our funders, DAERA and Ards and North Down Borough Council this fabulous facility couldnrsquot have become a reality.ldquoThe club are also extremely grateful to the Ulster Community Investment Trust Ltd who provided vital access to finance through their third sector loan fund.Mr Coulter added: ldquoIt is fantastic to see the buzz around the club and so many people joining from surrounding towns.ldquoHaving over  members demonstrates that there really was a demand for a facility such as this, which will help our club, parish and surrounding communities to become fitter and healthier for generations to come.You can find out more by following The Camaacuten Fitness Suite on Facebook..prettyPhoto

title: Ballygowan lecturer appointed veterinary association president
story: SIMON Doherty, a Ballygowan-based veterinary consultant and senior lecturer at Queenrsquos University Belfast, has been elected President of the British Veterinary Association.His appointment was confirmed last week during the Associationrsquos annual membersrsquo day at the National STEM Learning Centre in York.The British Veterinary Associationis the national representative body for the veterinary profession in the UK, representing the views of over , members on animal health and welfare and veterinary policy issues to government, parliamentarians and key influencers in the UK and EU.Simon said it is a ldquoreal honour to be appointed the BVArsquos president at a time when it is critical for the organisation to provide a strong voice for vets.ldquoWe are a relatively small profession, but the BVA has a growing membership who are becoming increasingly engaged due to cross-cutting concerns around issues such as workforce capacity and capability, he explained.ldquoHowever, itrsquos also an exciting time when many vets are exploring the ersity of available career paths, novel working patterns and the opportunities afforded through leadership and innovation.Simon has confirmed that the theme for his presidential year is lsquoone veterinary communityrsquo which builds upon past presidents John Fishwick and Gudrun Ravetzrsquos themes of lsquoTeam Vet ndash Working Togetherrsquo and lsquoThe Veterinary Familyrsquo respectively.His theme encapsulates the crucial role of the veterinary profession at the regional, national and global levels and recognises the importance of continued collaboration with key stakeholders within the profession and with members of the wider animal health and welfare sector.Simon graduated as a veterinary surgeon from the University of Glasgow in  after which he worked for five years in mixed practice in West Stirlingshire in Scotland and closer to home in North Down.He was also instrumental in setting up Veterinary Northern Irelandas a lsquoone-stop shoprsquo for the local veterinary associations in the Province.In , Simon was appointed as a Veterinary Research Officer at the Veterinary Sciences Division of the Agri-Food  Biosciences Institute at Stormont where his research interests included novel vaccine technologies in farm and aquaculture species, colostrum management in dairy systems and the detection and control of epizootic diseases.Simon was appointed an honorary lecturer in animal health and welfare at Queenrsquos in  and ed to the private sector in . The following year, he set up Blackwater Consultancy Ltd, which works with companies to drive inward investment and support export trade in the animal health and aquaculture sectors.For three years, the Ballygowan vet was the animal sciences and aquaculture specialist for the Department for International Trade and in June this year was appointed to a senior role within the Institute of Global Food Security at Queenrsquos.He is involved in teaching, curriculum development and commercial interactions relating to animal health and aquaculture. Simon is also a past president of the NI Veterinary Association and of the Northern Ireland Branch of BVA.Simon has authored many peer-reviewed scientic papers, tech-transfer articles and reports on a wide range of animal health and welfare issues and is also actively involved in the provision of veterinary careers advice, regularly mentoring applicants to veterinary school..prettyPhoto

title: Ballylone Flute Band celebrates 110th anniversary
story: BALLYLONE Concert Flute Band celebrated eleven decades of music making, with a dinner at Temple Golf Club on Saturday night.The band has seven flute sections mdash piccolo, trebles, concerts, altos, basses, contra bass, and sub-contra bass, as well as percussion.The conductor since  has been Philip Walton, who is also deputy conductor of the Ulster Orchestra, and the arranger is Alan Trimble. Craig McAllister has succeeded his father, David, as Drum Major.Competing since , the band became Flute Band  champions in ,  and , and World Senior Flute Band champions in , , ,  and .On Saturday night Mr Walton was kept busy handing out a large number of long service awards. Looking to the future, members of the young learnersrsquo class received their certicates from the Royal Schools of Music.The band was formed in  from local families in Ballylone townland. This family basis continues to the present day, with additional talent drawn from farther afield. lsquoFamilyrsquo means extended family, with fathers, sons, daughters, husbands and wives all taking part.This year has been special for one Ballylone family, with the passing of band veteran Ainsley Harrison. Ainsleyrsquos father, Bill, was a founder member, who served  years as secretary. Four of his grandchildren and seven of his great grandchildren play in todayrsquos band. His sons, Sam and Ainsley, joined the band, naturally.During WW band practice was suspended for three years and the instruments were stored on the Harrison farm. Young Ainsley took the opportunity to become proficient on every iety of flute. He eventually served for  years as flautist and was appointed band president on retirement from playing.On his death his children requested that memorial donations in lieu be given for the bandrsquos benefit. They then purchased a new Trevor James alto flute, and presented it in Ainsleyrsquos memory. This flute is now played on parades by his daughter, Sandra.David Burrows, from another Ballylone family, received a clock in appreciation of his  yearsrsquo service. His we recently retired from the band and three daughters and two of his grandchildren are members. He and Ainsley were instrumental in the rebuilding of Ballylone Hall in .Saturday nightrsquos dinner was a thoroughly enjoyable occasion, celebrating the bandrsquos past and looking forward to its future. title: Charitable cyclists hand over cheque to Mainstay
story: BIG-HEARTED cyclists have raised pound, for Mainstay DRP in Downpatrick.Philip Todd, Paddy Moore and Claire Magennis, three members of the Mainstay DRP management committee, were joined by Jim McMullan, Greer Lowe and another man also Paddy Moore for a fund-raising cycle along the Northern Ireland coast.Even the weather couldnrsquot hold them back as they cycled  miles from Derry to Newry over four days to raise vital funds for the charityrsquos work.On the third day they rode  miles around Strangford Lough and in total, they climbed , feet over the four days.A spokesman for Mainstay DRP, which works with adults with learning disabilities and or autism, said: ldquoFor those of you interested, thatrsquos , pedal revolutions and an average of  miles per hour.ldquoIt was a huge success and the efforts of all involved should be applauded.The charity hopes to run another cycle, of a similar duration, in June next year.Anyone interested in taking part is asked to get in touch with the charity on    option  and ask to speak to Kate..prettyPhoto

title: Davy’s double delight
story: THE winning combination of trainer Gordon Elliott and jockey Davy Russell recorded yet another double at Downpatrick on Friday.The Co Meath guru, who has his large team in great form at the moment, brought his total for the year at the track to  with one meeting remaining on October , while Russell is on nine.The duo got off to a flying start when Star Maker got the better of hot favourite Kellyiscool, who had made the long trip form Limerick, in the ITBA Northern Region Supporting Local Racecourses maiden hurdle, back in third was Korolena.They then joined forces in the third race of the day, the Molson Coors maiden hurdle, where Thisonesforollie got up in the closing stages under Russellrsquos strong driving to better Conor Orr on Whatsyourstatus.In an extremely close finish, the   favourite got the verdict by a neck with Court Adjourned and Adam Short  s back in third place.The meeting produced three long-priced winners. The first of these came in the second race, a handicap hurdle over two miles two furlongs, when Authorative, a   outsider in the well known black and red spots of Rita Shah, made every post a winning one to beat Eight and Bob with top weight Milomynt third.For Co Armagh teenager Shane OrsquoCallaghan, who also rides on the flat, it was his first ever winner in what has been a short career. The horse is trained by his boss Anthony McCann, who was also on lead up duties, in Co Monaghan mdash he has had some good priced winners of late.The second long-priced winner came in the Irish Stallion Farms beginners chase when   shot Ard Na Carraig, with Barry Browne in the saddle, won from Andrew Lynch on Moon ball with the   favourite Native Lass in third.This one being one of two runners in the race from the Co Cork yard of Michael Winters. Oliver McKiernan, who is based near Dublin, was recoding his second recent success.The third big-priced winner came in the Frank Fitzsimons Memorial handicap hurdle when Rachael Blackmore looked like adding another win to her impressive tally for the year when her mount Peacockrsquos Secret still held a good advantage going over the last.It then looked like Wee Tiger was going to snatch the honours, only for Brien Kane to come with a late surge on   shot Doolough Lad in the colours of Sligo owner trained Michael Hallinan to win from   favourite Wee Tiger with Peacockrsquos Secret third.It was a first success for Hallinan and a late spare for Kane after intended rider Cathal Landers was taken to hospital following an early fall in the dayrsquos second race. The unlucky rider was later reported to have a fractured sternum.The Killultagh Estares novice hurdle saw the most popular winner of the day when Sir Benford Wales, in the colours of Ballygowan publican Jonathan Flanagan and trained in Co waterford by Henry De Bromhead, eased to an impressive win.The winner was another success for this seasonrsquos leading jump jockey Rachael Blackmore.Always travelling well, the partnership won from recent Down Royal winner lysis Naturea in the colours of Templepatrick owner Karen McNeilly. This one was ridden as usual by Karen Ferris and back in third was early leader Tegany. SP:   fav,  ,  .The final race on the card was the Molson Coors flat race and Co Meath owner trainer Hugh Finegan had a welcome change of luck when Happy Lad, with Derek OrsquoConnor on board, won in good style from Gordon Elliottrsquos Miss Aloud, ridden by Jamie Codd. Even money favourite Salty Boy finished third.The wait is over this Saturday for the Mid Antrim point-to-point Autumn meeting at Moneyglass. Bad news for supporters is entry fee, including a race card is pound, compared to pound entry and pound race card.Newry trainer Liam Lennon wishes to thank all those that gave him sponsorship in aid of the Injured Jockeyrsquos Fund at a recent golf tournament.A recent evening geld in the Canal Court Hotel in memory of Kelly Hadden , who sadly lost her long, hard battle with cancer, raised over pound, for the Cancer Unit at Belfast City Hospital.Kelly, who was unlucky not to ride a winner as an amateur at point-to-point meetings, did train her own horse to win a point-to-point at Kirkistown under the handling of Jason McKeown.Her mother, Frances, wishes to thank everyone for their support, not only on the night, but also during Kellyrsquos illness..prettyPhoto

title: Dramatic late scores hand win to Ballycran
story: A SENSATIONAL goal and a point in added time from Conor Woods enabled Ballycran to pinch the Jeremiah McVeagh Cup from under Portaferryrsquos noses at Mitchel Park, Ballygalget, on Sunday afternoon.Portaferry had seized the initiative in the th minute when they took a - to - lead mdash a lead they increased to seven points by the st minute. Someone failed to read theto Ballycran and they slowly reeled Portaferry in.However, they still trailed - to - going into added time, but a point from Gerard Hughes breathed new le into their challenge and Woods delivered the dramatic coup de grace with a stunning strike from a free and he then finished the job off with a point from play.Colin Murrayrsquos full time whistle was met with jubilation by celebrating Ballycran players and supporters who invaded the pitch to congratulate their heroes, while stunned Portaferry mentors couldnrsquot believe they had just lost the game.Two Colm McManus frees gave Ballycran an early advantage before Matthew Conlon and Conor Mageean brought the sides level by the th minute.A Cormac McAllister goal had Ballycran back in the driving seat, but Portaferry patiently hit back with consecutive points from Ronan Blairand a Conor OrsquoPrey rsquo to take a - to - lead.Blair increased that lead to five points when he drilled in a cracking goal in the rd minute and this was followed by quick points from Eoghan Sands and Tom Murray as Portaferry went into the break with a commanding - to - lead.Scott Nicholson and Blair twice swapped points before Nicholson and McManus left five points between the sides with  minutes remaining.The accurate Blair and Woods swapped points before Liam Savage made it - to - with  minutes left.The tension was rising the longer the game went on, but it was Ballycran who had the bit between their teeth and after Blair and Nicholson had exchanged points, James Coyle, Niall Fitzsimons and Gerard Hughes all grabbed points to leave two points between the sides deep into added time.It was then that Woods swooped when he mercilessly drilled a m free to the net, despite Portaferryrsquos valiant efforts to keep the daisy cutter from hitting the back of the net.Just to rub salt into the wounds, Woods added a point from play to give his side their first SHC title since  and condemn Portaferry to their second consecutive championship final defeat, having lost out to Ballygalget last year by a singe point.Ballycran: Stephen Keith, Michael Hughes, Barry Flynn, Sean Ennis, Michael Taylor, Patrick Hughes, Brett Nicholson, Scott Nicholson , Phelim Savage , Cormac McAllister , Conor Woods , Liam Savage , James Coyle , Colm McManus , Niall Breen. Subs: Gerard Hughes for Breen, Andy Bell for Taylor, Declan Ennis for Keith.Portaferry: Karol Keating, Neil White, Conor OrsquoNeill, Darragh Mallon, Michael Conlon , Caolan Taggart, Conor OrsquoPrey , Conor Fay, Conor Mageean , Aaron OrsquoPrey, Kevin McGarry, Barry Trainor, Ronan Blair , Eoghan Sands , Daithi Sands. Subs: Tom Murrayfor Fay, Niall Fitzsimonsfor Trainor, Paul Branf for McGarry, Conor Fay for Aaron OrsquoPrey. Ballycran -Portaferry -MORGAN FUELS SHC FINAL.prettyPhoto

title: Fantástico%2C Emma
story: LOUGHINISLAND girl Emma Branf has been named as the top Spanish student in the UK and Ireland.The  year-old former Assumption Grammar School student was given the accolade by the Spanish Embassy in the UK and Ireland at a ceremony held at IES Vicente Cantildeada Blanch in London.Itrsquos the first time the award has gone to a student from Northern Ireland.Emma was accompanied to the awards ceremony by her proud mother, Francesca.She and her teachers were also rewarded with a tour of the IES Cantildeada Blanch School, the only bilingual Spanish and English School in the United Kingdom and Ireland, located in London.Emma said: ldquoI am delighted with this achievement but I must also pay tribute to the quality of language teaching in Assumption Grammar. I wouldnrsquot be where I am todayit had not been for my teachers there.School principal Peter Dobbin said that he was thrilled that the honour went to Emma and the schoolrsquos Languages Department.ldquoEmma richly deserved this public recognition of what she has achieved, he said. ldquoIt also highlights the crucial importance of learning languages as a le skill for all our young people.ldquoI am privileged to lead a school with an incredible Languages Department, with top performing linguists who continuously inspire the Assumption pupils.Mr Dobbin explained that the award acknowledges not only the results achieved in Spanish but also performance in other subjects across the curriculum at A Level.ldquoOur Head of Spanish, James Leonard, leads a department which continues to set the highest of standards in the United Kingdom and Ireland. Our Assumption pupils are blessed to have such a talented linguist at the helm, he added.Mr Leonard described Emma as a ldquostar student, with no Spanish background, yet naturally gted, and excels at a level which surpasses all expectation.Lynsey Patton, who taught Emma for six years, and who identied and nurtured her potential in languages, added: ldquoIt has been a joy to watch her develop linguistically. She certainly has a bright future ahead.Emmarsquos prize is a three-day visit to the region of Castilla y Leoacuten, which she will embark upon in early .She is currently taking a gap year, working in Paris, and will continue her linguistic studies at university next year..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C October 3%2C 1978
story: NEWCASTLE mdash A drastic slump in support for Newcastle Town Committee has thrown its future in the balance mdash and a special meeting in a fortnightrsquos time could decide whether it will carry on.Lack of support from the public, traders, clubs and organisations at last weekrsquos annual meeting has confronted the town committee with a major crisis and it may need a big increase in interest to persuade it to carry on.The town committee was formed four years ago to promote the area as a tourist attraction and since then the fortunes of Newcastle have improved dramatically.Mr Bill Martin, town committee chairman, was clearly disappointed at the lack of public support and in a hard-hitting attack he called for more people to come forward and lend their weight to the committee.ldquoItrsquos shattering to think that only a handful of people are prepared to come to our annual meeting, he said. ldquoHow can we make Newcastle the top report in the provincewersquore not going to get the necessary support from the townspeople Mr Martin was critical of the apathy surrounding the town, considering the big steps it has taken over the last few years.Since the committeersquos formation the townrsquos trade and tourism has boomed, yet he claims the same old faces are having to do all the hard work.ldquoMy feelings are stronger than Irsquom prepared to say. Really, our committee must seriously question the need to go on. Is it worthwhile staying in existencewe are not backed by the people ldquoThe committeersquos path is at a crossroads and it is us who must decide the future. Which way we go will ultimately depend on the turnout at our next meeting.Mr Gerry Toner, another founder member of the committee, was also shocked at the appalling turnout at last weekrsquos meeting.ldquoI think it is very sad that the business people in the town are not prepared to come forward to do something positive for the area, he said.BALLYNAHINCH mdash A Ballynahinch familyrsquos running protest against Down councillors took another turn this week with a noisy protest outside the councilrsquos headquarters in Downpatricik.Mrs Gemma Rice and her children began chanting and banging tin cans as councillors held their fortnightly meeting.In recent weeks the family has been mounting a silent picked outside the council offices when there are meetings in progress. They claim that councillors have done nothing to help them solve the smoke problem at their Carlisle Park home.The chanting outside the meeting went on for well over an hour. Inside, councillors decided against calling in the police as there were children involved. They closed the windows in the chamber and tried to speak over the noise from outside.DOWNPATRICK mdash Down councillors are staying firmly on course with their plans to open a major dumping site in a picturesque area less than half a mile from the Quoile River, outside Downpatrick.Despite facing a mounting wall of protest from planners and conservationists, councillors decided this week to stick to their guns and push ahead with the scheme.The site eats up almost  acres of land, about half a mile from Quoile Yacht Club, and the council scheme entails a six-feet excavation of the entire area.Pollution controllers at Stormont have already come out against the scheme because they fear it could pollute the nearby Quoile River and local planners have received many complaints from conservationists.Even councillors themselves are split and some launched into fierce opposition of the scheme at this weekrsquos council meeting.Downpatrick councillor George Flinn, whose home is less than a five-minute walk from the river, was the sternest critic and he pulled no punches in an open attack on the plan.ldquoI am appalled that a council which prides itself on being forward-looking should be asked to agree to the vandalising of one of the areas of outstanding natural beauty within its district.KILLYLEAGH mdash Residents of Killyleagh and Shrigley have called for a full debate on the future of the harbour site and possible marina plans. It will be top of the list for discussion when the local town committee holds their annual meeting in January .Other matters to be discussed at the AGM are law and order and the future of the vandalised community hall. Senior representatives of the RUC will be invited to attend.The town committee wishes to advise all residents of Killyleagh and Shrigley that its meetings are held on the last Thursday of every month. Any matters of general communal interest which they wish to be discussed should be communicated to committee members.PORTAFERRY mdash A Portaferry motorist and his front seat passenger were killed instantly on Saturday when their car collided head-on with an Ulsterbus.Police are still trying to determine the cause of the accident which killed Mr Trevor Mahood, of Shore Road, and Mr David McVeigh, of Lawson Gardens, Portavogie.The crash occurred at the Kingrsquos Corner blackspot between Greyabbey and Kircubbin. Another passenger in the car is still seriously ill in hospital. The bus driver and two passengers on the bus were slightly injured.CROSSGAR mdash Plans have been drawn up to make Lissara Presbyterian Churchrsquos annual harvest fair on Saturday a bigger lsquoknockoutrsquo than usual. One of the ideas being introduced to make the fair a major success is a local version of the renowned TV show lsquoItrsquos a Knockoutrsquo.Teams for dferent congregations in Crossgar district will compete in a iety of games introduced by Mr Dermot Nesbitt in the War Memorial Hall. The fun doesnrsquot begin until .pm, but there are many other things to keep visitors busy during the afternoon.KILCOO mdash A local missionary, Sister Alphonsus Devlin, from Kilcoo, is at present home on vacation from Pakistan where she teaches in a diocese of . million people.She works under very strenuous conditions where the extreme heat in the summer causes many diseases, as well as drought, and where living standards are very low.Before going back to Pakistan she has been trying to thank local people for their prayers, moral support and donations which were sent over.CASTLEWELLAN mdash Castlewellan Lake has proved to be a happy hunting ground recently for many local anglers, according to figures released by the Department of Agriculture.One Castlewellan fisherman, Jerry Mullan, netted a three-quarter pound rainbow trout and a lb brown trout from the lake recently, while other anglers reported good catches.DUNDRUMmdash Murlough Nature Reserve, Dundrum, will be setting for a series of winter walks starting this Sunday. The scheme is being organised by the National Trust and follows a series of successful summer walks.RACING mdash A record attendance of over , turned up at Downpatrick racecourse on Saturday to pay tribute to triple Grand National winner Red Rum.Probably the most famous racehorse of modern times, Red Rum revelled in the attention shown by thousands of admiring fans.Posing for the camera, allowing himself to be stroked and petted have all become part of Rummyrsquos le.Host to Red Rum and his entourage was Mr Jeremy Maxwell, chairman of Downpatrick Race Supporters Club. ldquoWe have had a most successful day andwe have done anything surely we have shown to the government what is obvious to most people that Downpatrick racecourse is very much alive..prettyPhoto

title: Giant Castlewellan tree shortlisted for accolade
story: A GIANT Redwood tree with  trunks in Castlewellan Forest Park has been shortlisted for the Woodland Trustrsquos Tree of the Year competition for .The Giant Redwood has been associated with Castlewellan Castle back to the s when the castle was built.The treersquos history is linked to all the plant hunters and explorers of the time who risked their lives bringing back exotic plants from thousands of miles away.Itrsquos believed to have been grown from the very first Giant Sequoia seeds brought back to England from Calornia in .Three years later, the third Earl Annesley obtained ten small samplings from England in and planted some of them in the Walled Garden at Castlewellan Castle, which was their family home at the time.The Holm Oak at Kibroney Park in Rostrevor was crowned Northern Irelandrsquos Tree of the Year in .Newry, Mourne and Down District Council chairman Mark Murnin is urging all the districtrsquos residents to vote for the Giant Redwood.ldquoIt would be wonderfulanother tree within the council area won this year, he said. ldquoIt is gratying to have one of our most venerable trees nominated for this prestigious award.ldquoI have seen this tree many times, and it is truly magnicent. The Giant Redwood attracts visitors from around the world, and is much loved by local families.To vote please do so before am, Monday, October , by visiting www.woodlandtrust.org.uk treeoftheyearvote..prettyPhoto

title: Kielty appointed integrated education patron
story: DUNDRUM comedian Patrick Kielty has become a patron and supporter for the Northern Ireland Council for Integrated Education.The US-based father-of-two hit the headlines last weekend for his Twitter explanation of the implications of Brexit on both sides of the Irish border.He joins Carl Frampton, Liam Neeson and Sir Kenneth Branagh as celebrity patrons of the Council.Earlier this year, Patrick authored a landmark documentary for BBC, lsquoMy Dad, The Peace Deal and Mersquo, which explored the legacy of Northern Irelandrsquos peace deal  years on. The documentary received audience and critical acclaim.He said of his support for integrated education: ldquoIf we want to change the future we need to start with our kids, letting them discover what they have in common.He also referred to a visit to Shimna Integrated College in Newcastle.ldquoWhen I visited Shimna Integrated College earlier this year it was great to see young people with opposing political opinions freely expressing themselves as friends, he said.ldquoWersquore one society made up from dferent backgrounds, not two communities. Letrsquos celebrate it and move forward together..prettyPhoto

title: Local historical society celebrates 70th anniversary
story: THE Lecale and Downe Historical Society recently celebrated seven decades of preserving and promoting the history and heritage of Lecale and County Down.At a th anniversary dinner at Denvirrsquos Hotel mdash the original meeting place of the society in  mdash a three course meal was enjoyed by  members and friends.A presentation of an engraved gavel was made by Mr Johnny Dooher, of the Federation of Ulster Local Studies.Following the dinner and refreshments the special guest for the evening, eminent Irish historian Dr Eamon Phoenix, gave his address on the lsquoDecade of Centenariesrsquo of -.Mr Roderick Downer, chair of the society, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be celebrating this milestone in the societyrsquos own history and to mark it.ldquoIt was wonderful to have so many members of the society, from all walks of le, join together for an enjoyable evening with a riveting talk by Dr Phoenix.The society will also be celebrating  years of continuous publishing when it launches the latest edition of Lecale Review in November.The Review is an eclectic mix of historical stories from the area. This yearrsquos edition will include articles such as a history of the Hollymount estate near Downpatrick, shipwrecks of Co Down, the Home Guard post WW and a story entitled lsquoThe Great Cat of Cloughrsquo..prettyPhoto

title: Lord Eames to talk at lecture
story: LORD Eames, the former Church of Ireland primate, will be the guest speaker at the Saint Patrick Centre in Downpatrick this Friday evening.His talk, entitled lsquoSaint Patrick, Armagh and the search for Common Groundrsquo, is the second of the Legacy Autumn Lecture Series at the centre.Lord Eames was the longest-serving Archbishop of Armagh and the most senior primate in the Anglican Communion.The high points of his ecclesiastical career were often on the international stage. A lawyer by training and a cleric by vocation, he served as Chairman of the Lambeth Commission on Communion, which produced the Windsor Report in October .He has been awarded many accolades, including nine honorary doctorates and the Freedom of the City of Armagh.Fridayrsquos lecture begins at pm and admission is free..prettyPhoto

title: Loughinisland author delves into legacy of St Patrick
story: THE St Patrickrsquos Treasury is a unique celebration of the myths, legends and traditions of Irelandrsquos patron saint.Written by Loughinisland man John Killen, author and former chief librarian at the Linenhall Library in Belfast, it reflects a long-held interest in the le, writings and legacy of St Patrick.Beautully illustrated, this book from Blackstaff Press includes information on places associated with Patrick, such as Downpatrick, Saul, Armagh, Cashel and Slemish.It also examines ious religious relics and traditions associated with one of the best-known and best-loved saints in the world.Itrsquos an accessible yet meticulous approach, which has been a labour of love for John, who brings together the stories that have been associated with St Patrick across the centuries. Of particular interest to local readers will be sections on Saul mdash the place of Patrickrsquos landing.Observing the interest of those outside Ireland on St Patrick, John began thinking seriously about his book project five years ago.He said: ldquoSt Patrick is so obviously supported across the world ndash what is it that causes that support ldquoI was brought up outside Downpatrick in Loughinisland. I assumed I knew everything about St Patrick. I wanted to see ndash what do we know about St Patrick  I wanted to go back. I wanted an anthology of peoplersquos writings throughout the centuries, build up a picture of what he was and what he means throughout our history over , years.John said some of his findings were a ldquototal surprise, such as the article by Maureen Donnelly lsquoThe Altar Stone of Saul Abbeyrsquo. This details how the altar stone on which Patrick is said to have celebrated Holy Communion ended up on a wagon owned by a man who wanted it for the doorstep of his new house at the junction of Saul Street and Scotch Street in . But the wagon overturned, the stone broke and it found its way instead to the Catholic Church in Saul.ldquoI never realised there was an altar stone of St Patrick actually in Saul chapel, John said. ldquoI went three times to try and see it. I could not get in the first time as there was a ceremony on. It took me a bit of time to find it. This is one of the earliest and possibly holiest relics in Ireland open to all to see.John said he was also ldquoblown away by a stained-glass window, lsquoPatrick Arrives in Saulrsquo, in Saul Chapel.ldquoThe three windows are designed so the three windows show one image, he explained. ldquoIt is absolutely beautul.John is the author of many books, including The Irish Christmas Book and The Unkindest Cut: A Cartoon History of Ulster -, as well as books on the Irish famine and the United Irishmen.Surrounded by sites linked to our patron saint in Downpatrick, John believes at times we ldquocanrsquot see the woods from the trees.He points to the massive success of less important sites in the south, or how such a historical location would promoted ldquoto the nth degree in the US.ldquoI think that is the challenge for people here today, he said. ldquoThere is so much scope, there really is. I think we lose the wood from the trees. So many stories, so many things to pursue.Interestingly, his research points to an attitude from some in the south of Patrick being a ldquonorthern saint. There is also, of course, the increased secularisation of Ireland.ldquoBut there are still a massive amount of people who are people of faith, John continued.ldquoWe live in an area of huge historical importance. Because we are so familiar we often just take it for granted.The St Patrickrsquos Treasury is available through selected bookstores and online retailers such as Amazon..prettyPhoto

story: BALLYNAHINCH kept their % record on Saturday, sweeping aside their derby rivals with ease.The lsquoHinch ran riot for  minutes, never looking like they were going go leave with anything less than three points.It didnrsquot take long for Ballynahinch to take the lead. title: Seal stranded on Murlough Beach
story: THIS young stricken seal was at the centre of a drama on Murlough Beach last week.Named as Panoramix, it emerged that the one-year-male ended up stranded on the beach after leaving its colony in Wexford.Several hours later as local National Trust wardens kept an eye on him, Panoramix finally was able to summon enough strength toto the water.The seal was spotted last Tuesday by Dundrum conservationist Seamus King as he scanned Dundrum bay from his telescope in his apartment.He soon realised that the seal was in dficulty as he seemed unable to move.Mr King said: ldquoThis was about pm and I saw that the seal was exhausted and had dficulty getting back into the water.ldquoIt seemed not to be moving at all and for a time I wonderedit was still alive.Seamus, who is a RSPB member and a volunteer with Mourner Heritage Trust, knew not to interfere with the seal but to seek expert advice.ldquoI called the seal manager, Amy Robinson, at Portaferry, and she contacted Sea Rescue Ireland who askedI could get close enough to get more information, said Mr King.ldquoWith the help of two National Trusts wardens, I approached the seal to take a picture of its tag. I was told that it was a young male from Sea Rescue Ireland in Wexford, not one of our own seal colony which live on the Ballykinlar side of Dundrum bay.The agreed plan of action was to keep an eye on the seal and to leave it overnight to seeit had moved before taking it to Exploris to safety the next day.Mr King adds: ldquoThe greatest danger was that he could have become more stressed had there been for example a dog in the area, or a walker getting too close. Any approach can make a seal more anxious.ldquoWe were able to establish some time later, thanks to our two National Trust friends, that had ed safely to the water, sometime between -pm..prettyPhoto

title: Ulster Bank site is put on the market
story: THE former Ulster Bank in Killyleagh has been put on the market for sale.The High Street branch closed earlier this year with the move criticised by customers who said the decision would have a major impact on the town.The branch was one of eight the Ulster Bank closed mdash a decision which bank officials described as ldquodficult.In a bid to soften the blow, officials said the bank provides customers with more ways to bank than ever before. They explained the way people bank has changed radically over the past few years with a signicant reduction in the number of customers using branches.Rowallane councillor Billy Walker, a former customer of the bank, hopes a buyer can be found for the property.ldquoThis is a prime site and I hope there is a willing buyer to redevelop the building and hopefully provide a number of new jobs, he said.Cllr Walker said he hoped the building will not be lying empty for too much longer.He added: ldquoThe building has been empty since last May and I hope the sale will generate interest in the former bank branch which I believe has much to offer potential buyers in the centre of the town..prettyPhoto

title: fermanaghs high streets have a lot to offer
story: It feels like itrsquos been much longer than just a few weeks when the skyline of Belfast became darkened with thick black smoke.On that late August day, thousands of people tuned into ious live streams to watch the old Bank Building as it burnt, thankful that there hadnrsquot been any loss of le or injury, but also awestruck at the sheer destruction that was unfolding before their eyes.The building that was home to Primark in Belfast was pretty iconic. Evenyou didnrsquot know the first thing about the place other than it was old, it was still clearly an important part of the history of Belfast.After the fire, the past of the Bank Buildings became known and many lamented at the thought of losing such a piece of the past: for it to be turned to rubble and replaced with something nondescript. Itrsquos easy to forget that while inanimate, buildings do have character and tell the story of a city in a way that brings it right into the present.But with all that said, it seems now that the fire has been extinguished, some seem more concerned with preserving what is left of the building rather than putting the le back into Belfast. While it has been deemed structurally sound, some debris has still been falling when the wind has swooped through in the wrong direction and with the first storm of the season forecast for this week, the real integrity will only be known now.For more than a fortnight, a firm cordon has been put in place around the burnt-out building and businesses in the immediate area have reported a severe drop in trade, with some stating their footfall has fallen by more than half. With the cordon expected to be in place until after Christmas, there are fourteen businesses within it who cannot open at all.Thatrsquos not to say that nothing is being done to try and help those businesses.Belfast City Council is working with other agencies to try and find alternative premises for these businesses and to ensure that they will not be left out of pocket for something that essentially amounted to sheer bad luck.For businesses still open but noticing a fall in trade, signage has been placed to direct people around the cordon to ensure they can still move around the city centre. Translink too are doing their bit by offering a free shuttle bus that goes from St. Georges Market to the city centre every ten minutes.Events such as fashion shows and promotional meals have been scheduled and there has also been the launch of the ldquoYour Belfast campaign which aims to encourage shoppers back into the city.Irsquod say that you canrsquot fault them for trying, but I do see a few issues with all that is going on.Itrsquos not that I begrudge Belfast having their campaign. I really donrsquot. Their local economy is certainly going to have taken a hit following the fire and hats off to those trying to make the best of the bad situation, but I donrsquot think theyrsquore going about it in the best way.If people want to go to Primark, then put on subsidised shuttle buses for them. The company seem to have been brilliant in looking after their staff and sending them off to other stores despite losing thousands of profit a day with the loss of their flagship store and should be supported for that.If you look at the list of businesses that are completely closed due to the fire, they include the likes of Tesco, a charity shop, McDonalds and of course, Primark. Only three or four of the shops would be generally considered higher end and are places where you plan to go to rather than just meander into as yoursquore passing.If I was in Belfast and need to pick up groceries or want to seethere are any gems in the charity shops, a free bus to Victoria Square isnrsquot going to do me much good.A fashion show showcasing the latest designer trends Belfast has to offer isnrsquot going to be of much interest to those who focus on affordability rather than ensuring that a print or certain cut is in vogue.As the news of the Primark fire broke, many people spoke of how both they and their parents before them had depended on the storersquos low prices when times were tough. To see a campaign promoting higher cost clothing must feel a little insensitive to those who now are worrying about where theyrsquoll be buying their winter jumpers and endless pairs of gloves to replace those that keep getting lost in the schoolyard.We wouldnrsquot have had the ldquoYour Belfast marketing campaign had it not been for the Primark fire so I can understand why it is focused on Belfast, but I feel that therersquos huge scope to promote the whole of Northern Ireland as viable alternatives.We all know that Belfast is still open for business so no amount of cajoling is going to make someone go therethey donrsquot want to but perhaps those in Belfast arenrsquot as aware of what other towns across the province have to offer.The advert lists qualities that Belfast is said to have but itrsquos nothing unique. Here in Enniskillen, wersquore also strong, proud and together. We too have great local music to offer and can offer a great night out. We also love our food, enjoy shopping trips and look out for one another.We may not have had a fire, but our high street needs support too. Traders have been complaining about high rents and rates for years so therersquos quite a high turnover rate of independent shops and small chain branches.People go to where the cheapest prices are but small businesses canrsquot afford to lower their prices to match local competition so they risk losing out on trade. Itrsquos a situation where no-one really wins. If the Belfast campaign is to be a more long-term one, then they should widen it to include everywhere. Promote the highlights of each county and make it accessible to all.If Translink brought back opentickets, Irsquom sure wersquod see a marked increase in people coming here for a weekend break. Some people are understandably cautious of driving in unfamiliar places, especially towns but four hours on a bus in one day doesnrsquot leave much time for relaxing or shopping.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: denzil mcdaniel the scene should be set to build for the future on the wonderful asset of ardhowen
story: Over the years, Irsquove enjoyed a few entertaining performances at the Ardhowen and not all of them were on the stage.In the mid-s, Fermanagh District Council meetings were held in the old building, before the marvellous new theatre was built. A bomb had damaged Enniskillen Townhall, and for a while the Council moved out to the Ardhowen.Pardon the pun, but there were times when Council meetings were ldquoas good as a play, as my granny used to say. Reporting the meetings for the paper was enjoyable, and I remember on one occasion two Councillors had a, er, lively exchange of views and we all held our breath as John Joe McCusker marched down the chamber to confront Jim Lunny.Of course it all ended amicably. The two men, both Nationalists and both with a mischievous sense of humour, were very dferent characters ndash genuine characters and not the fictional types which would tread the boards later at the same venue. I got to know them both and enjoyed their company.Jim Lunny was a great campaigner for retaining townland names, and John Joe fought his corner for his area. I recall them both having a sense of community, and not only would they do their best for Fermanagh in their day, both were also conscious of the need to pass things on to future generations.So they were very supportive of the then Chief Executive, Gerry Burns, a public servant with real vision, when he was the driving force to transform the Ardhowen into the beautul ldquoTheatre by the Lakes. And the architecture-award winning building became the envy of many places at home and abroad.Pardon the clicheacute, but the ldquojewel in the crown was an apt description, but more than just being a beautul building in a beautul setting, the Ardhowen under the dedicated and expert guidance of people like Eamonn Bradley and others, gave a real boost to the arts and entertainment.Enniskillen, and indeed Fermanagh generally, has a fine tradition in amateur drama and itrsquos gratying to see the likes of Adrian Dunbar and Ciaran McMenamin go on to have distinguished careers. About four years ago, I had the pleasure of chairing the Xchange summer school at the Ardhowen when Adrian spoke of his passion for the arts and as a regular visitor to his home town he still boosts the arts here. As does Ciaran, who engaged locals at such events as the film club. The range of activities at the Ardhowen is ied and we are, indeed, fortunate to have such a venue.Itrsquos starting to show its age, though. Even so, I cannot imagine that the people who got the theatre project up and running  years ago would have expected that already the Council is undertaking an exercise to look at the future of the theatre. Some of the options include an upgrade or extension, but worryingly another option is to build another theatre on another site.All this has been well reported by Colm Bradley in this newspaper.The situation has led to a number of people expressing doubts about the future of the Ardhowen, and Fermanagh Film Clubrsquos Jules Caithness wrote about ldquograve concern at the fog of uncertainty over the theatre which he said had been ldquohorribly neglected.The Council attempted to downplay this by saying they have ldquono plans to sell the Ardhowen site.No plans  Whatthey go for the option of a new theatre on a new site  What happens to the Ardhowen site then  Irsquod have preferred a straightforward, no wersquore not selling it. Itrsquos a uniquely beautul site and wersquod be mad to sell it.Irsquom told a meeting was held in August of ldquostakeholders which unsettled some of those present, and that no Councillors were present.Irsquom wondering how the succeeding Councils over the years allowed the building to get into such a state of repair, to the point where they now need to spend a large sum of money.So much money, in fact, that it exceeds the threshold that an ldquoeconomic appraisal is required.Irsquom sure some bean counter will weigh it all up but how do you place on a balance sheet the richness of cultural experience which the Ardhowen has brought to Fermanagh over three decades, and the reputation our centre of excellence has across Ireland In the current climate, I think the way we are governed isnrsquot as ldquoopen and accountable as it should be. There is certainly a massive disconnect between the people and those in authority at Stormont, though one would expect thatany public body would have the ear of the public it would be the local Council.Some decisions have implications for years to come. I still get annoyed when I walk past the old ldquostreets area opposite the police station in Enniskillen and see a lot of public sector buildingswhere once stood a thriving community of people living in homes on the island.OK, housing conditions were awful, but homes should have been built there instead of what the planners did with the area.So, please members of Fermanagh and Omagh District Council, consider carefully what you do with the Ardhowen. Itrsquos not really yours, and itrsquos not totally a matter of money.Part of the problem, apparently, is a lack of car parking. Aside from the fact that this would suggest itrsquos a popular venue, surely itrsquos not beyond the Council to sort that one out There are other problems, of course, and I fully accept that these are stringent times.Butyoursquore looking for feedback, Councillors, mine is that you should recognise what a magnicent asset you have on your hands. Pluck the jewel out of the crown and abandon it at your peril. In fact, find the money, go the whole hog and turn the ldquotheatre by the lakes into an even greater asset which will build on what has already been achieved and be lauded for years to come.Your predecessors, McCusker, Lunny and Burns among other, had the foresight to do that.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: ruas winter fair to become important dairy showcase
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast.Speaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and ten native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and chairman David Connolly said: Itrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.French judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors.ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.ABERDEEN ANGUSA strong entry of Aberdeen Angus calves were judged by William McLaren from the noted Netherton Herd based at Blackford in Perthshire.Stealing the limelight in the junior section was the -month-old heer, Home Farm Ebony Stunner bred by Fintan Keown, Belleek.
